translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GLORIFY naught besides, O friends; so shall no sorrow trouble you. Praise only mighty Indra when the juice is shed, and say your lauds repeatedly:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even him, eternal, like a bull who rushes down, men's Conqueror, bounteous like a cow; Him who is cause of both, of enmity and peace, to both sides most munificent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Although these men in sundry ways invoke thee to obtain thine aid, Be this our prayer, addressed, O Indra, unto thee, thine exaltation every day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those skilled in song, O Maghavan among these men o’ercome with might the foeman's songs. Come hither, bring us strength in many a varied form most near that it may succour us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Caster of the Stone, I would not sell thee for a mighty price, Not for a thousand, Thunderer! nor ten thousand, nor a hundred, Lord of countless wealth!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, thou art more to me than sire or niggard brother is. Thou and my mother, O Good Lord, appear alike, to give me wealth abundantly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where art thou? Whither art thou gone? For many a place attracts thy mind. Haste, Warrior, Fort-destroyer, Lord of battle's din, haste, holy songs have sounded forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing out the psalm to him who breaks down castles for his faithful friend, Verses to bring the Thunderer to destroy the forts and sit on Kaṇva's sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Horses which are thine in tens, in hundreds, yea, in thousands thine, Even those vigorous Steeds, fleet-footed in the course, with those come quickly near to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This day I call Sabardughā who animates the holy song, Indra the richly-yielding Milch-cow who provides unfailing food in ample stream.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Sūra wounded Etaśa, with Vāta's rolling winged car. Indra bore Kutsa Ārjuneya off, and mocked Gandharva. the unconquered One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He without ligature, before making incision in the neck, Closed up the wound again, most wealthy Maghavan, who maketh whole the injured part.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we be never cast aside, and strangers, as it were, to thee. We, Thunder-wielding Indra, count ourselves as trees rejected and unfit to burn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vṛtra-slayer, we were thought slow and unready for the fray. Yet once in thy great bounty may we have delight, O Hero, after praising thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If he will listen to my laud, then may out Soma-drops that flow Rapidly through the strainer gladden Indra, drops due to the Tugryas’ Strengthener.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come now unto the common laud of thee and of thy faithful friend. So may our wealthy nobles’ praise give joy to thee. Fain would I sing thine eulogy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Press out the Soma with the stones, and in the waters wash it clean. The men investing it with raiment made of milk shall milk it forth from out the stems.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether thou come from earth or from the lustre of the lofty heaven, Wax stronger in thy body through my song of praise: fill full all creatures, O most Wise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For India press the Soma out, most gladdening and most excellent. May Śakra make it swell sent forth with every prayer and asking, as it were, for strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let me not, still beseeching thee with earnest song at Soma rites, Anger thee like some wild beast. Who would not beseech him who hath power to grant his prayer?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The draught made swift with rapturous joy, effectual with its mighty strength, All-conquering, distilling transport, let him drink: for he in ecstasy gives us gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where bliss is not, may he, All-praised, God whom the pious glorify, Bestow great wealth upon the mortal worshipper who sheds the juice and praises him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Indra, and rejoice thyself, O God, in manifold affluence. Thou fillest like a lake thy vast capacious bulk with Soma and with draughts besides.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A thousand and a hundred Steeds are harnessed to thy golden car. So may the long-maned Bays, yoked by devotion, bring Indra to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yoked to thy chariot wrought of gold, may thy two Bays with peacock tails, Convey thee hither, Steeds with their white backs, to quaff sweet juice that makes us eloquent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So drink, thou Lover of the Song, as the first drinker, of this juice. This the outpouring of the savoury sap prepared is good and meet to gladden thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who alone by wondrous deed is Mighty, Strong by holy works, May he come, fair of cheek; may he not stay afar, but come and turn not from our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Śuṣṇa's quick moving castle thou hast crushed to pieces with thy bolts. Thou, Indra, from of old, hast followed after light, since we have had thee to invoke.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: My praises when the Sun hath risen, my praises at the time of noon, My praises at the coming of the gloom of night, O Vasu, have gone forth to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise yea, praise him. Of princes these are the most liberal of their gifts, These, Paramajyā, Ninditāśva, Prapathī, most bounteous, O Medhyātithi.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When to the car, by faith, I yoked the horses longing for the way- For skilled is Yadu's son in dealing precious wealth, he who is rich in herds of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he who gave me two brown steeds together with their cloths of gold, May he, Āsaṅga's son Svanadratha, obtain all joy and high felicities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Playoga's son Āsaṅga, by ten thousand, O Agni, hath surpassed the rest in giving. For me ten bright-hued oxen have come forward like lotus-stalks from out a lake upstanding.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time her husband's perfect restoration to his lost strength and manhood was apparent, His consort Śaśvatī with joy addressed him, Now art thou well, my lord, and shalt be happy. Next: HYMN II. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HERE is the Soma juice expressed; O Vasu, drink till thou art full: Undaunted God, we give it thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Washed by the men, pressed out with stones, strained through the filter made of wool, ’Tis like a courser bathed in stream.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This juice have we made sweet for thee like barley, blending it with milk. Indra, I call thee to our feast.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Beloved of all, Indra alone drinks up the flowing Soma juice Among the Gods and mortal men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Friend, whom not the brilliant-hued, the badly-mixt or bitter draught, Repels, the far-extending God;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: While other men than we with milk chase him as hunters chase a deer, And with their kine inveigle him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For him, for Indra, for the God, be pressed three draughts of Soma juice In the juice-drinker's own abode.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three reservoirs exude their drops, filled are three beakers to the brim, All for one offering to the God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pure art thou, set in many a place, and blended in the midst with milk And curd, to cheer the Hero best.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here, Indra, are thy Soma-draughts pressed out by us, the strong, the pure: They crave admixture of the milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, pour in milk, prepare the cake, and mix the Soma-draught. I hear them say that thou art rich.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Quaffed juices fight within the breast. The drunken praise not by their wine, The naked praise not when it rains.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rich be the praiser of one rich, munificent and famed like thee: High rank be his, O Lord of Bays.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Foe of the man who adds no milk, he heeds not any chanted hymn Or holy psalm that may he sung.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us not, Indra, as a prey unto the scornful or the proud: Help, Mighty One, with power and might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This, even this, O Indra, we implore. as thy devoted friends, The Kaṇvas praise thee with their hymns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Naught else, O Thunderer, have I praised in the skilled singer's eulogy: On thy land only have I thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gods seek him who presses out the Soma; they desire not sleep They punish sloth unweariedly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither swift with gifts of wealth - be not thou angry with us-like A great man with a youthful bride.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let him not, wrathful with us, spend the evening far from us to-day, Like some unpleasant son-in-law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For well we know this Hero's love, most liberal of the boons he gives, His plans whom the three worlds display.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour forth the gift which Kaṇvas bring, for none more glorious do we know Than the Strong Lord with countless aids.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O presser, offer Soma first to Indra, Hero, Śakra, him The Friend of man, that he may drink;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who, in untroubled ways, is best provider, for his worshippers. Of strength in horses and in kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressers, for him blend Soma juice, each draught most excellent, for him The Brave, the Hero, for his joy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Vṛtra-slayer drinks the juice. May he who gives a hundred aids Approach, nor stay afar from us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the strong Bay Steeds, yoked by prayer, bring hither unto us our Friend, Lover of Song, renowned by songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sweet are the Soma juices, come! Blent are the Soma juices, come! Ṛṣi-like, mighty, fair of cheek, come hither quickly to the feast.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And lauds which strengthen thee for great bounty and valour, and exalt Indra who doeth glorious deeds,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And songs to thee who lovest song, and all those hymns addressed to thee- These evermore confirm thy might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus he, sole doer of great deeds whose hand holds thunder, gives us strength, He who hath never been subdued.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vṛtra he slays with his right hand, even Indra, great with mighty power, And much-invoked in many a place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He upon whom all men depend, all regions, all achievements, he Takes pleasure in our wealthy chiefs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All this hath he accomplished, yea, Indra, most gloriously renowned, Who gives our wealthy princes strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who drives his chariot seeking spoil, from afar, to him he loves: For swift is he to bring men wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Sage who, winning spoil with steeds, slays Vṛtra, Hero with the men, His servant's faithful succourer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Priyamedhas, worship with collected mind this Indra whom The Soma hath full well inspired.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Kaṇvas, sing the Mighty One, Lord of the Brave, who loves renown, All-present, glorified by song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong Friend, who, with no trace of feet, restores the cattle to the men, Who rest their wish and hope on him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shaped as a Ram, Stone-hurler I once thou camest hither to the son Of Kaṇva, wise Medhyātithi.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vibhindu, thou hast helped this man, giving him thousands four times ten, And afterward eight thousand more.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And these twain pouring streams of milk, creative, daughters of delight, For wedlock sake I glorify. Next: HYMN III. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: DRINK, Indra, of the savoury juice, and cheer thee with our milky draught. Be, for our weal, our Friend and sharer of the feast, and let thy wisdom guard us well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thy kind grace and favour may we still be strong: expose us not to foe's attack. With manifold assistance guard and succour us, and bring us to felicity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May these my songs of praise exalt thee, Lord, who hast abundant wealth. Men skilled in holy hymns, pure, with the hues of fire, have sung them with their lauds to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, with his might enhanced by Ṛṣis thousandfold, hath like an ocean spread himself. His majesty is praised as true at solemn rites, his power where holy singers rule.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra for worship of the Gods, Indra while sacrifice proceeds, Indra, as worshippers in battle-shock, we call, Indra that we may win the spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With might hath Indra spread out heaven and earth, with power hath Indra lighted up the Sun. In Indra are all creatures closely held; in him meet the distilling Soma-drops.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men with their lauds are urging thee, Indra, to drink the Soma first. The Ṛbhus in accord have lifted up their voice, and Rudras sung thee as the first.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra increased his manly strength at sacrifice, in the wild rapture of this juice. And living men to-day, even as of old, sing forth their praises to his majesty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I crave of thee that hero strength, that thou mayst first regard this prayer, Wherewith thou holpest Bhṛgu and the Yatis and Praskaṇva when the prize was staked.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wherewith thou sentest mighty waters to the sea, that, Indra, is thy manly strength. For ever unattainable is this power of him to whom the worlds have cried aloud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Help us, O Indra, when we pray to thee for wealth and hero might. First help thou on to strength the man who strives to win, and aid our laud, O Ancient One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Help for us, Indra, as thou holpest Paura once, this man's devotions bent on gain. Help, as thou gavest Ruśama and Śyāvaka and Svarṇara and Kṛpa aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What newest of imploring prayers shall, then, the zealous mortal sing? For have not they who laud his might, and Indra-power won for themselves the light of heaven?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When shall they keep the Law and praise thee mid the Gods? Who counts as Ṛṣi and as sage? When ever wilt thou, Indra Maghavan, come nigh to presser's or to praiser's call?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These songs of ours exceeding sweet, these hymns of praise ascend to thee, Like ever-conquering chariots that display their strength, gain wealth, and give unfailing aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bhṛgus are like Suns, like Kaṇvas, and have gained all that their thoughts were bent upon. The living men of Priyamedha's race have sung exalting Indra with their lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best slayer of the Vṛtras, yoke thy Bay Steeds, Indra, from afar. Come with the High Ones hither, Maghavan, to us, Mighty, to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For these, the bards and singers, have cried out to thee with prayer, to gain the sacrifice. As such, O Maghavan, Indra, who lovest song, even as a lover bear my call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou from the lofty plains above, O Indra, hurledst Vṛtra down. Thou dravest forth the kine of guileful Mṛgaya and Arbuda from the mountain's hold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright were the flaming fires, the Sun gave forth his shine, and Soma, Indra's juice, shone clear. Indra, thou blewest the great Dragon from the air: men must regard that valorous deed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The fairest courser of them all, who runneth on as ’twere to heaven. Which Indra and the Maruts gave, and Pākasthāman Kaurayāṇ.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To me hath Pākasthāman given, a ruddy horse, good at the pole, Filling is girth and rousing wealth;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Compared with whom no other ten strong coursers, harnessed to the pole, Bear Tugrya to his dwelling place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Raiment is body, food is life, and healing ointment giveth strength. As the free-handed giver of the ruddy steed, I have named Pākasthāman fourth. Next: HYMN IV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOUGH, Indra, thou art called by men eastward and westward, north and south, Thou chiefly art with Ānava and Turvaśa, brave Champion I urged by men to Come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Or, Indra, when with Ruma, Ruśama, Śyāvaka, and Kṛpa thou rejoicest thee, Still do the Kaṇvas, bringing praises, with their prayers, O Indra, draw thee hither: come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as the wild-bull, when he thirsts, goes to the desert's watery pool, Come hither quickly both at morning and at eve, and with the Kaṇvas drink thy fill.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the drops gladden thee, rich Indra, and obtain bounty for him who pours the juice. Soma pressed in the mortar didst thou take and drink, and hence hast won surpassing might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With mightier strength he conquered strength, with energy he crushed their wrath. O Indra, Strong in youth, all those who sought the fray bent and bowed down to thee like trees.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who wins promise of thine aid goes girt as with a thousand mighty men of war. He makes his son preeminent in hero might: he serves with reverential prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With thee, the Mighty, for our Friend, we will not fear or feel fatigue. May we see Turvaśa and Yadu: thy great deed, O Hero, must be glorified.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On his left hip the Hero hath reclined himself: the proffered feast offends him not. The milk is blended with the honey of the bee: quickly come hither, baste, and drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, thy friend is fair of form and rich in horses, cars, and kine. He evermore hath food accompanied by wealth, and radiant joins the company.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come like a thirsty antelope to the drinking-place: drink Soma to thy heart's desire. Raining it down, O Maghavan, day after day, thou gainest thy surpassing might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Priest, let the Soma juice flow forth, for Indra longs to drink thereof. He even now hath yoked his vigorous Bay Steeds: the Vṛtra-slayer hath come near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man with whom thou fillcst thee with Soma deems himself a pious worshipper. This thine appropriate food is here poured out for thee: come, hasten forward. drink of it,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Press out the Soma juice, ye priests, for Indra borne upon his car. The pressing-stones speak loud of Indra, while they shed the juice which, offered, honours him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To the brown juice may his dear vigorous Bay Steeds bring Indra, to our holy task. Hither let thy Car-steeds who seek the sacrifice bring thee to our drink-offerings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pūṣan, the Lord of ample wealth, for firm alliance we elect. May he with wisdom, Śakra! Looser! Much-invoked! aid us to riches and to seed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sharpen us like a razor in the barber's hands: send riches thou who settest free. Easy to find with thee are treasures of the Dawn for mortal man whom thou dost speed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pūṣan, I long to win thy love, I long to praise thee, Radiant God. Excellent Lord, ’tis strange tome, no wish have I to sing the psalm that Pajra sings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: My kine, O Radiant God, seek pasture where they will, my during wealth, Immortal One. Be our protector, Pūṣan! be, most liberal Lord, propitious to our gathering strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rich was the gift Kurunga gave, a hundred steeds at morning rites. Among the gifts of Turvaśas we thought of him, the opulent, the splendid King.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What by his morning songs Kaṇva, the powerful, hath, with the Priyamedhas, gained-

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The herds of sixty thousand pure and spotless kine, have I, the Ṛṣi, driven away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The very trees were joyful at my coming: kine they obtained in plenty, steeds in plenty. Next: HYMN V. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHEN, even as she were present here, red Dawn hath shone from far away, She spreadeth light on every side.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like Heroes on your will-yoked car farshining, Wonder-Workers! ye Attend, O Aśvins, on the Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By you, O Lords of ample wealth our songs of praise have been observed: As envoy have I brought the prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kaṇvas must praise the Aśvins dear to many, making many glad, Most rich, that they may succour us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most liberal, best at winning strength, inciters, Lords of splendour who Visit the worshipper's abode.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So for devout Sudeva dew with fatness his unfailing mead, And make it rich for sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hitherward running speedily with horses, as with rapid hawks, Come, Aśvins, to our song of praise

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wherewith the three wide distances, and all the lights that are in heaven. Ye traverse, and three times of night.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Finders of the Day, that we may win us food of kine and wealth, Open the paths for us to tread.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, bring us wealth in kine, in noble heroes, and in cars: Bring us the strength that horses give.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Lords of splendour, glorified, ye Wonder-Workers borne on paths Of gold, drink sweets with Somajuice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To us, ye Lords of ample wealth, and to our wealth chiefs extend Wide shelter, ne’er to be assailed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come quickly downward to the prayer of people whom ye favour most: Approach not unto other folk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Aśvins whom our minds perceive, drink of this lovely gladdening draught, The mcath which we present to you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring riches hither unto us in hundreds and in thousands, source Of plenteous food, sustaining all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Verily sages call on you, ye Heroes, in full many a place. Moved by the priests, O Aśvins, conic.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men who have trimmed the sacred grass, bringing oblations and prepared, O Aśvins, are invoking you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this our hymn of praise to-day, most powerful to bring you, be, O Aśvins, nearest to your hearts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The skin filled full of savoury meath, laid in the pathway of your car- O Aśvins, drink ye both therefrom.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For this, ye Lords of ample wealth, bring blessing for our herd, our kine, Our progeny, and plenteous food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye too unclose to us like doors the strengthening waters of the sky, And rivers, ye who find the day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When did the son of Tugra serve you, Men? Abandoned in the sea, That with winged steeds your car might fly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye, O Nāsatyas, ministered to Kaṇva with repeated aid, When cast into the heated pit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come near with those most recent aids of yours which merit eulogy, When I invoke you, Wealthy Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As ye protected Kaṇva erst, Priyamedha and Upastuta, Atri, Sinjara, Aśvins Twain

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And Amsu in decisive fight, Agastya in the fray for kine. And, in his battles, Sobhari.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For so much bliss, or even more, O Aśvins, Wealthy Gods, than this, We pray white singing hymns to you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ascend your car with golden seat, O Aśvins, and with reins of gold, That reaches even to the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Golden is its supporting shaft, the axle also is of gold, And both the wheels are made of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thereon, ye Lords of ample wealth, come to us even from afar, Come ye to this mine eulogy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From far away ye come to us, Aśvins, enjoying plenteous food Of Dāsas, O Immortal Ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With splendour, riches, and renown, O Aśvins, hither come to us, Nāsatyas, shining brilliantly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May dappled horses, steeds who fly with pinions, bring you hitherward To people skilled in sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The whcel delayeth not that car of yours accompanied by song, That cometh with a store of food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Borne on that chariot wrought of gold, with coursers very fleet of foot, Come, O Nāsatyas, swift as thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Wealthy Gods, ye taste and find the brisk and watchful wild beast good. Associate wealth with food for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, O Aśvins, find for me my share of new-presented gifts, As Kasu, Cedi's son, gave me a hundred head of buffaloes, and ten thousand kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who hath given me for mine own ten Kings like gold to look upon. At Caidya's feet are all the people round about, all those who think upon the shield.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No man, not any, goes upon the path on which the Cedis walk. No other prince, no folk is held more liberal of gifts than they. Next: HYMN VI Indra

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA, great in his power and might, and like Parjanya rich in rain, Is magnified by Vatsa's lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the priests, strengthening the Son of Holy Law, present their gifts, Singers with Order's hymn of praiser.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Since Kaṇvas with their lauds have made Indra complete the sacrifice. Words are their own appropriate arms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Before his hot displeasure all the peoples, all the men, bow down, As rivers bow them to the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This power of his shone brightly forth when Indra brought together, like A skin, the worlds of heaven and earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The fiercely-moving Vṛtra's head he severed with his thunderbolt, His mighty hundred-knotted bolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here are-we sing them loudly forth-our thoughts among-the best of songs. Even lightnings like the blaze of fire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When bidden thoughts, spontaneously advancing, glow, and with the stream Of sacrifice the Kaṇvas shine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, may we obtain that wealth in horses and in herds of cows, And prayer that may be noticed first.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I from my Father have received deep knowledge of the Holy Law I was born like unto the Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: After the lore of ancient time I make, like Kaṇva, beauteous songs, And Indra's selfgains strength thereby.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever Ṛṣis have not praised thee, Indra, or have lauded thee, By me exalted wax thou strong.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When his wrath thundered, when he rent Vṛtra to pieces, limb by limb, He sent the waters to the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Against the Dasyu gusna thou, Indra, didst hurl thy during bolt: Thou, Dread one, hast a hero's fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Neither the heavens nor firmaments nor regions of the earth contain Indra, the Thunderer with his might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra him who lay at length staying thy copious waters thou, In his own footsteps, smotest down

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou hiddest deep in darkness itim, O Indra, who had set his grasp On spacious heaven and earth conjoined.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, whatever Yatis and Bhṛgus have offered praise to thee, Listen, thou Mighty, to my call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, these spotted cows yield thee their butter and the milky draught; Aiders, thereby, of sacrifice;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Which, teeming, have received thee as a life-germ, Indra, with their mouth, Like Sūrya who sustaineth all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Lord of Might, with hymns of praise the Kaṇvas have increased thy power, The drops poured forth have strengthened thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Under thy guidance, Indra, mid thy praises, Lord of Thunder, shall The sacrifice be soon performed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, disclose much food for us, like a stronghold with store of kine: Give progeny and heroic strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, Indra, grant us all that wealth of fleet steeds which shone bright of old Among the tribes of Nahusas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither thou seemest to attract heaven's fold which shines before our eyes, When, Indra, thou art kind to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, when thou puttest forth thy power, Indra, thou governest the folk. Mighty, unlimited in strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The tribes who bring oblations call to thee, to thee to give them help, With drops to thee who spreadest far.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: There where the mountains downward slope, there by the meeting of the streams The Sage was manifest with song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thence, marking, from his lofty place downward he looks upon the sea, And thence with rapid stir he moves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then, verify, they see the light refulgent of primeval seed, Kindled on yonder side of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, the Kaṇvas all exalt thy wisdom and thy manly power, And, Mightiest! thine heroic strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept this eulogy of mine, Indra, and guard me carefully: Strengthen my thought and prosper it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thee, O Mighty, Thunder-armed, we singers through devotionhave Fashioned the hymn that we may live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra have the Kaṇvas sung, like waters speeding down a slope: The song is fain to go to him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As rivers swell the ocean, so our hymns of praise make Indra strong, Eternal, of resistIess wrath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come with thy lovely Bay Steeds, come to us from regions far away O Indra, drink this Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best slayer of Vṛtras, men whose sacred grass is ready trimmed Invoke thee for the gain of spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The heavens and earth come after thee as the wheel follows Etaśa: To thee flow Soma-drops effused.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rejoice, O Indra, in the light, rejoice in Saryandyan, be Glad in the sacrificer's hymn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grown strong in heaven, the Thunder-armed hath bellowed, Vṛtra-slayer, Bull, Chief drinker of the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art a Ṛṣi born of old, sole Ruler over all by might: Thou, Indra, guardest well our wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May thy Bay Steeds with beauteous backs, a hundred, bring thee to the feast, Bring thee to these our Soma-draughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Kaṇvas with their hymns of praise have magnified this ancient thought That swells with streams of meath and oil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mid mightiest Gods let mortal man choose Indra at the sacrifice, Indra, whoe’er would win, for help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy steeds, by Priyamedhas praised, shall bring thee, God whom all invoke, Hither to drink the Somajuice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hundred thousand have I gained from Parsu, from Tirindira, And presents of the Yadavas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ten thousand head of kine, and steeds three times a hundred they bestowed On Pajra for the Sāma-song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kakuha hath reached up to heaven, bestowing buffaloes yoked in fours, And matched in fame the Yadavas. Next: HYMN VII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O MARUTS, when the sage hath poured the Tṛṣṭup forth as food for you, Ye shine amid the mountain-clouds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Bright Ones, fain to show your might ye have determined on your course, The mountain-clouds have bent them down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loud roaring with the winds the Sons of Pṛśni have upraised themselves: They have poured out the streaming food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts spread the mist abroad and make mountains rock and reel, When with the winds they go their way

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the rivers and the hills before your coming bowed them down, So to sustain your mighty force.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call on you for aid by night, on you for succour in the day, On you while sacrifice proceeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These, verily, wondrous, red of hue, speed on their courses with a roar Over the ridges of the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With might they drop the loosened rein so that the Sun may run his course, And spread themselves with beams of light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept, ye Maruts, this my song, accept ye this mine hymn of praise, Accept, Ṛbhukṣans, this my call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The dappled Cows have poured three lakes, meath for the Thunder-wielding God, From the great cask, the watery cloud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, quickly come to us when, longing for felicity, We call you hither from the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Rudras and Ṛbhukṣans, ye, Most Bountiful, are in the house, Wise when the gladdening draught is drunk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, send us down from heaven riches distilling rapturous joy, With plenteous food, sustaining all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Bright Ones, hither from the hills ye have resolved to take your way, Ye revel in the drops effused.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Man should solicit with his lauds happiness which belongs to them, So great a band invincible.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They who like fiery sparks with showers of rain blow through the heaven and earth, Milking the spring that never fails.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With chariots and tumultuous roar, with tempests and with hymns of praise The Sons of Pṛśni hurry forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For wealth, we think of that whereby ye aided Yadu, Turvaśa, And KanVa who obtained the spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May these our viands Bounteous Ones I that flow in streams like holy oil, With Kaṇva's hymns, increase your might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where, Bounteous Lords for whom the grass is trimmed, are ye rejoicing now? What Brahman is adoring you?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Is it not there where ye of old, supplied with sacred grass, for lauds Inspired the strong in sacrifice?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They brought together both the worlds, the mighty waters, and the Sun, And, joint by joint, the thunderbolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They sundered Vṛtra limb from limb and split the gloomy mountain-clouds, Performing a heroic deed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They reinforced the power and strength of Trita as he fought, and helped Indra in battle with the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They deck themselves for glory, bright, celestial, lightning in their hands, And helms of gold upon their heads.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When eagerly ye from far away came to the cavern of the Bull, He bellowed in his fear like Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Borne by your golden-footed steeds, O Gods, come hither to receive The sacrifice we offer you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the red leader draws along their spotted deer yoked to the car. The Bright Ones come, and shed the rain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Susoma, Saryakiavan, and Arjika full of homes, have they. These Heroes, sought with downward car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Maruts, ye come to him, the singer who invokes you thus, With favours to your suppliant?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What now? where have ye still a friend since ye left Indra all alone? Who counteth on your friendship now?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Kaṇvas sing forth Agni's praise together with our Maruts’ who Wield thunder and wear swords of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither for new felicity may I attract the Impetuous Ones, The Heroes with their wondrous strength

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Before them sink the very hills deerning themseives abysses: yea, Even the mountains bend them down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Steeds flying on their tortuous path through mid-air carry them, and give The man who lauds them strength and life.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni was born the first of all, like Sūrya lovely with his light: With lustre these have spread abroad. Next: HYMN VIII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH all the succours that are yours, O Aśvins, hither come to us: Wonderful, borne on paths of gold, drink ye the meath with Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come now, ye Aśvins, on your car decked with a sun-bright canopy, Bountiful, with your golden forms, Sages with depth of intellect.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither from the Nahusas, come, drawn by pure hymns, from mid-air. O Aśvins, drink the savoury juice shed in the Kaṇvas' sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us hither from the heavens, come from mid-air, well-loved by us: Here Kaṇva's son hath pressed for you the pleasant meath of Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Aśvins, to give car to us, to drink the Soma, Aśvins, come. Hail, Strengtheners of the praise-song speed onward, ye Heroes, with your thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As, Heroes, in the olden time the Ṛṣis called you to their aid, So now, O Aśvins, come to us, come near to this mine eulogy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even from the luminous sphere of heaven come to us, ye who find the light, Carers for Vatsa, through our prayers and lauds, O yewho hearour call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do others more than we adore the Aśvins with their hymns of praise? The Ṛṣi Vatsa, Kaṇva's son, hath magnified you with his songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The holy singer with his hymns hath called you, Aśvins, hither-ward; Best Vṛtra-slayers, free from stain, as such bring us felicity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time, ye Lords of ample wealth, the Lady mounted on your car, Then, O ye Aśvins, ye attained all wishes that your hearts desired.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come thence, O Aśvins, on your car that hath a thousand ornaments: Vatsa the sage, the sage's son, hath sung a song of sweets to you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cheerers of many, rich in goods, discoverers of opulence, The Aśvins, Riders through the sky, have welcomed this my song of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, grant us all rich gifts wherewith no man mav interfere. Make us observe the stated times: give us not over to reproach.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether, Nāsatyas, ye be nigh, or whether ye be far away, Come thence, O Aśvins, on your car that hath a thousand ornaments.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vatsa the Ṛṣi with his songs, Nāsatyas, hath exalted you: Grant him rich food distilling oil, graced with a thousand ornaments.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bestow on him, O Aśvins, food that strengthens, and that drops with oil, On him who praises you for bliss, and, Lords of bounty, prays for wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us, ye who slay the foe, Lords of rich treasure, to this hymn. O Heroes, give us high renown and these good things of earth for help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Priyamedhas have invoked you with all succours that are yours, You, Aśvins, Lords of solemn rites, with calls entreating you to come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us, Aśvins, ye Who bring felicity, auspicious Ones, To Vatsa who with prayer and hymn, lovers of song, hath honoured you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aid us, O Heroes, for those hymns for which ye helped GoSarya erst, Gave Vaśa, Dasavraja aid, and Kaṇva and Medhatithi:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And favoured Trasadasyu, ye Heroes, in spoil-deciding fray: For these, O Aśvins, graciously assist us in acquiring strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, may pure hymns of ours, and songs and praises, honour you: Best slayers everywhere of foes, as such we fondly yearn for you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three places of the Aśvins, erst concealed, are made apparent now. Both Sages, with the flight of Law come hither unto those who live. Next: HYMN IX. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To help and favour Vatsa now, O Aśvins, come ye hitherward. Bestow on him a dwelling spacious and secure, and keep malignities away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All manliness that is in heaven, with the Five Tribes, or in mid-air, Bestow, ye Aśvins, upon us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Remember Kaṇva first of all among the singers, Aśvins, who Have thought upon your wondrous deeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, for you with song of praise this hot oblation is effused, This your sweet Soma juice, ye Lords of ample wealth, through which ye think upon the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever ye have done in floods, in the tree, Wonder-Workers, and in growing plants, Therewith, O Aśvins, succour me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What force, Nāsatyas, ye exert, whatever, Gods, ye tend and heal, This your own Vatsa gains not by his hymns alone: ye visit him who offers gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now hath the Ṛṣi splendidly thought out the Aśvins' hymn of praise. Let the Atharvan pour the warm oblation forth, and Soma very rich in sweets.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Aśvins, now ascend your car that lightly rolls upon its way. May these my praises make you speed hitherward like a cloud of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, O Nāsatyas, we this day make you speed hither with our hymns, Or, Aśvins, with our songs of praise, remember Kanya specially.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As erst Kakṣīvān and the Ṛṣi Vyaśva, as erst Dīrghatamas invoked your presence, Or, in the sacrificial chambers, Vainya Pṛthi, so be ye mindful of us here, O Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come as home-guardians, saving us from foemen, guarding our living creatures and our bodies, Come to the house to give us seed and offspring,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether with Indra ye be faring, Aśvins, or resting in one dwelling-place with Vāyu, In concord with the Ṛbhus or Ādityas, or standing still in Viṣṇu's striding-places.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When I, O Aśvins, call on you to-day that I may gather strength, Or as all-conquering might in war, be that the Aśvins' noblest grace.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now come, ye Aśvins, hitherward: here are oblations set for you; These Soma-draughts to aid Yadu and Turvaśa, these offered you mid Kaniva's Sons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever healing balm is yours, Nisatyas, near or far away, Therewith, great Sages, grant a home to Vatsa and to Vimada.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Together with the Goddess, with the Aśvins' Speech have I awoke. Thou, Goddess, hast disclosed the hymn, and holy gift from mortal men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Awake the Aśvins, Goddess Dawn! Up Mighty Lady of sweet strains! Rise, straightway, priest of sacrifice! High glory to the gladdening draught!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Dawn, approaching with thy light shinest together with the Sun, And to this man-protecting home the chariot ofthe Aśvins comes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When yellow stalks give forth the juice, as cows from udders pour their milk, And voices sound the song of praise, the Aśvins' worshippers show first.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Forward for glory and for strength, protection that shall conquer men, And power and skill, most sapient Ones!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Aśvins, worthy of our lauds, ye seat you in the father's house. With wisdom or the bliss ye bring. Next: HYMN X. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHETHER ye travel far away or dwell in yonder light of heaven, Or in a mansion that is built above the sea, come thence, ye Aśvins, hitherward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Or if for Manu.ye prepared the sacrifice, remember also Kaṇva's son. I call Bṛhaspati, Indra, Viṣṇu, all the gods, the Aśvins borne by rapid steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those Aśvins I invoke who work marvels, brought hither to receive, With whom our friendship is most famed, and kinship passing that of Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On whom the solemn rites depend, whose worshippers rise without the Sun: These who foreknow the holy work of sacrifice, and by their Godhead drink the sweets of Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether ye, Lords of ample wealth, now linger in the cast or west, With Druhyu, or with Anu, Yadu, Turvaga, I call you hither; come to me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lords of great riches, whether through the firmament ye fly or speed through heaven and earth, Or with your Godlike natures stand upon your cars, come thence, O Aśvins, hitherward. Next: HYMN XI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOU Agni, God mid mortal men, art guard of sacred rites, thou art To be adored at sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Mighty Agni, thou must be glorified at our festivals, Bearing our offerings to the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Jātavedas Agni, fight and drive our foes afar from us, Themand their godless enmities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Jātavedas, seekest not the worship of a hostile man, However nigh itbe to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We sages, mortals as we are, adore the mighty name oof thee, Immortal Jātavedas' name.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sages, we call the Sage to help, mortals, we call the God to aid: We call on Agni with our songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Vatsa draw- thy mind away even from thy loftiest dwelling-place, Agni, with song that yearns for thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art the same in many a place: mid all the people thou art Lord. In fray and fightt we call on thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When we are seeking strength we call Agni to help us in the strife, The giver of rich gifts in war.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ancient, adorablie at sacrifices, Priest from of old, meet for our praise, thou sittest. Fill full and satisfy thy body, Agni, and win us happiness by offering worship. Next: HYMN XII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: JOY, Mightiest Indra, known and marked, sprung most from Soma-draughts, wherewith Thou smitest down the greedy fiend, for that we long.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wherewith thou bolpest Adhrigu, the great Daśagva, and the God Who stirs the sunlight, and the sea, for that we long.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wherewith thou dravest forth like cars Sindhu and all the mighty floods To go the way ordained by Law, for that we long.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept this laud for aid, made pure like oil, thou Caster of the Stone, Whereby even in a moment thou hast waxen great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be pleased, Song-lover, with this song it flows abundant like the sea. Indra, with all thy succours thou hast waxen great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The God who from afar hath sent gifts to maintain our friendship's bond, Thou. spreading them like rain from heaven, hast waxen great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The beams that mark him have grown strong, the thunder rests between his arms, When, like the Sun, he hath increased both Heaven and Earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Mighty Lord of Heroes, thou didst cat a thousand buffaloes, Then grew and waxed exceeding great thine Indra-power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra consumeth with the rays of Sūrya the malicious man: Like Agni conquering the woods, he hath grown strong.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This newest thought of ours that suits the time approaches unto thee: Serving, beloved in many a place it metes and marks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The pious germ of sacrifice directly purifies the soul. By Indra's lauds it waxes great, it metes and marks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra who wins the friend hath spread himself to drink the Soma-draught: Like worshipper's dilating praise; it metes and marks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He whom the sages, living men, have gladdened, offering up their hymns, Hath swelled like oil of sacrifice in Agni's mouth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aditi also hath brought forth a hymn for Indra, Sovran Lord: The work of sacrifice for help is glorified.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The ministering priests have sung their songs for aid and eulogy: God, thy Bays turn not from the rite which Law ordains.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If, Indra, thou drink Soma by Viṣṇu's or Tṛta Āptya's side, Or with the Maruts take delight in flowing drops;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Or, Śakra, if thou gladden thee afar or in the sea of air, Rejoice thee in this juice of ours, in flowing drops.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Or, Lord of Heroes if thou aid the worshipper who shed; the, juice, Or him whose laud delights thee, and his flowing drops.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To magnify the God, the God, Indra, yea, Indra for your help, And promptly end the sacrifice-this have they gained.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With worship, him whom men adore, with Soma, him who drinks it most, Indra with lauds have they increasedthis have they gained.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His leadings are with power and might and his instructions manifold: He gives the worshipper all wealth: this have they gained.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For slaying Vṛtra have the Gods set Indra in the foremost place. Indra the choral bands have sung, for vigorous strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We to the Mighty with our might, with lauds to him who hears our call, With holy hymns have sung aloud, for vigorous strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not earth, nor heaven, nor firmaments contain the Thunder-wielding God: They shake before his violent rush and vigorous strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the Gods, O Indra, get thee foremost in the furious fight, Then thy two beautiful Bay Steeds carried thee on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Vṛtra, stayer of the floods, thou si"est, Thundeicr with might, Then thy two beautiful Bay Steeds carried thee on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When Viṣṇu, through thine energy, strode wide those three great steps of his, Then thy two beautiful Bay Steeds carried thee on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thy two beautiful Bay Steeds grew great and greater day by day, Even then all creatures that had life bowed down to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Indra, all the Marut folk humbly submitted them to thee, Even then all creatures that had life bowed down to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When yonder Sun, that brilliant light, thou settest in the heaven above, Even then all creatures that had life bowed down to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee, O Indra, with this thought the sage lifts up this eulogy, Akin and leading as on foot to sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When in thine own dear dwelling all gathered have lifted up the voice Milk-streams at worship's central spot, for sacrifice,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Priest, O Indra, give us wealth in brave men and good steeds ana kine That we may first remember thee for sacrifice. Next: HYMN XIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA, when Soma juices flow, makes his mind pure and meet for lauds. He gains the power that brings success, for great is he.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In heaven's first region, in the seat of Gods, is he who brings success, Most glorious, prompt to save, who wins the water-floods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, to win strength, have I invoked, even Indra mighty for the fray. Be thou most near to us for bliss, a Friend to aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, Song -lover, here for thee the worshipper's libation flows. Rejoicing in this sacred grass thou shinest forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even now, O Indra, give us that which, pressing juice, we crave of thee. Bring us wealth manifold which finds the light of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the zealous worshipper hath boldly sung his songs to thee, Like branches of a tree up-grows what they desire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Generate songs even as of old, give car unto the singer's call. Thou for the pious hast grown great at each carouse.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sweet strains that glorify him play like waters speeding down a slope, Yea, him who in this song is called the Lord of Heaven;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, who alone is called the Lord, the single Ruler of the folk, By worshippers seeking aid: may he joy in the draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise him, the Glorious, skilled in song, Lord of the two victorious Bays: They seek the worshipper's abode who bows in prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Put forth thy strength: with dappled Steeds come, thou of mighty intellect, With swift Steeds to the sacrifice, for ’tis thy joy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grant wealth to those who praise thee, Lord of Heroes, Mightiest Indra: give Our princes everlasting fame and opulence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I call thee when the Sun is risen, I call thee at the noon of day: With thy car-horses, Indra, come wellpleased to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Speed forward hither, come to us, rejoice thee in the milky draught: Spin out the thread of ancient time, as well is known.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If, Śakra, Vṛtra-slayer, thou be far away or near to us. Or in the sea, thou art the guard of Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let songs we sing and Soma-drops expressed by us make Indra strong: The tribes who bring oblations find delight in him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him sages longing for his aid, with offerings brought in eager haste, Him. even as branches, all mankind have made to grow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At the Trkadrukas the Gods span sacrifice that stirred the mind: May our songs strengthen him who still hath strengthened us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, true to duty, at due times the worshipper offers lauds to thee, They call him Purifier, Pure, and Wonderful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That mind of Rudra, fresh and strong, moves conscious in the ancient ways, With reference whereto the wise have ordered this.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If thou elect to be my Friend drink of this sacrificial juice, By help whereof we may subdue all enemies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Lover of the song, when shall thy praiser be most blest? When wilt thou grant us wealth in herds of kine and steeds?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And thy two highIy-lauded Bays, strong stallions, draw thy car who art Untouched by age, most gladdening car for which we pray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With ancient offerings we implore the Young and Strong whom many praise. He from of old hath sat upon dear sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wax miglity, thou whom many laud for aids which Ṛṣis have extolled. Pour down for us abundant food and guard us well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Caster of the Stone, thou helpest him who praises thee: From sacrifice I send to thee a mindyoked hymn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here, yoking for the Soma-draught these Horses, sharers of thy feast, Thy Bay Steeds, Indra, fraught with weal tb, consent to come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Attendants on thy glory, let the Rudras roar assent to thee, And all the Marut companies come tothe feast.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These his victorious followers bold in the heavens the place they love, Leagued in the heart of sacrifice, as well we know.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That we may long behold the light, what time the ordered rite proceeds, He duly measures, as he views, the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, strong is this thy car, and strong are these Bay Steeds of thine: O Śatakratu, thou art strong, strong is our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong is the press-stone, strong thy joy, strong is the flowing Soma juice: Strong is the rite thou furtherest, strong is our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As strong I call on thee the Strong, O Thunderer with thy thousand aids: For thou hast won the hymn of praise. Strong is our call. Next: HYMN XIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: IF I, O Indra, were, like thee, the single Sovran of all wealth, My worshipper should be rich in kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I should be fain, O Lord of Power, to strengthen and enrich the sage, Were I the Lord of herds of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To worshippers who press the juice thy goodness, Indra, is a cow Yielding in plenty kine and steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: None is there, Indra, God or man, to hinder thy munificence, The wealth which, lauded, thou wilt give.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The sacrifice made Indra strong when he unrolled the earth, and made Himself a diadem in heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine aid we claim, O Indra, thine who after thou hast waxen great Hast won all treasures for thine own.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In Soma's ecstasy Indra spread the firmament and realms of light, When he cleft Vala limb from limb.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Showing the hidden he drave forth the cows for the Aṅgirases, And Vala he cast headlong down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By Indra were the lumirious realms of heaven established and secured, Firm and immovable from their place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, thy laud moves quickly like a joyous wave of water-floods: Bright shine the drops that gladden thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou, O Indra, art the God whom hymns and praises magnify: Thou blessest those who worship thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the two long-maned Bay Steeds bring Indra to drink the Soma juice, The Bountiful to our sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With waters' foam thou torest off, Indra, the head of Namuci, Subduing all contending hosts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Dasyus, when they fain would climb by magic arts and mount to heaven, Thou, Indra, castest down to earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Soma-drinker conquering all, thou scatteredst to every side Their settlement who poured no gifts. Next: HYMN XV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING forth to him whom many men invoke, to him whom many laud. Invite the powerful Indra with your songs of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose lofty might-for doubly strong is he-supports the heavens and earth, And hills and plains and floods and light with manly power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Such, Praised by many! thou art King alone thou smitest Vṛtras dead, To gain, O Indra, spoils of war and high renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We sing this strong and wild delight of thine which conquers in the fray, Which, Caster of the Stone! gives room and shines like gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wherewith thou also foundest lights for Āyu and for Manu's sake: Now joying in this sacred grass thou beamest forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This day too singers of the hymn praise, as of old, this might of thine: Win thou the waters day by day, thralls of the strong.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That lofty Indra-power of thine, thy strength and thine intelligence, Thy thunderbolt for which we long, the wish makes keen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Heaven and Earth augment thy manly power and thy renown; The waters and thy mountains stir and urge thee on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Viṣṇu the lofty ruling Power, Varuṇa, Mitra sing thy praise: In thee the Marut3' company have great delight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, thou wast born the Lord of men, most liberal of thy gifts: Excellent deeds for evermore are all thine own.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ever, alone, O highly-praised, thou sendest Vṛtras to their rest: None else than Indra executes the mighty deed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Though here and there, in varied hymns, Indra, men call on thee for aid, Still with our heroes fight and win the light of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Already have all forms of him entered our spacious dwelling-place: For victory stir thou Indra, up, the Lord of Might. Next: HYMN XVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PRAISE Indra whom our songs must laud, sole Sovran of mankind, the Chief Most liberal who controlleth men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In whom the hymns of praise delight, and all the glory-giving songs. Like the floods' longing for the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him I invite with eulogy, best King, effective in the fight, Strong for the gain of mighty spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose perfect ecstasies are wide, profound, victorious, and give joy in the field where heroes win.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, when the spoils of war are staked, men call to be their advocate: They who have Indra win the day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men honour him with stirring songs and magnify with solemn rites: Indra is he who giveth case.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra is priest and Ṛṣi, he is much invoked by many men, And mighty by his mighty powers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Meet to be lauded and invoked, true Hero with his deeds of might, Victorious even when alone.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men, the people magnify that Indra with their Slina. songs, With hymns and sacred eulogies

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who advances them to wealth, sends light to lead them in the war, And quells their foemen in the fray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he, the saviour much-invoked, may Indra bear us in a ship Safely beyond all enemies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, O Indra, honour us with gifts of booty, further us, And lead us to felicity. Next: HYMN XVII Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COME, we have pressed the juice for thee; O Indra, drink this Soma here Sit thou on this my sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, let thy long-maned Bays, yoked by prayer, bring thee hitherward Give car and listen to our prayers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We Soma-bearing Brahmans call thee Soma-drinker with thy friend, We, Indra, bringing Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come unto us who bring the juice, come unto this our eulogy, Fair-visored! drink thou of the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I pour it down within thee, so through all thy members let it spread: Take with. thy tongue the pleasant drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sweet to thy body let it be, delicious be the savoury juice: Sweet be the Soma to thine heart.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like women, let this Soma-draught, invested with its robe, approach, O active Indra, close to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, transported with the juice, vast in his bulk, strong in his neck And stout arms, smites the Vṛtras down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, go thou forward, thou who rulest over all by might: Thou Vṛtra-slayer slay the fiends,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Long be thy grasping-hook wherewith thou givest ample wealth to him Who sheds the juice and worships thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here, Indra, is thy Soma-draught, made pure upon the sacred grass: Run hither, come and drink thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Famed for thy radiance, worshipped well this juice is shed for thy delight Thou art invoked, Akhandala!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Kundapayya, grandson's son, grandson of Srngavrs! to thee, To him have I addressed my thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong pillar thou, Lord of the home armour of Soma-offerers: The drop of Soma breaketh all the strongholds down, and Indra is the Ṛṣis’ Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Holy Prdikusanu, winner of the spoil, one eminent o’er many men, Lead on the wild horse Indra with his vigorous grasp forward to drink the Soma juice. Next: HYMN XVIII. Ādityas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now let the mortal offer prayer to win the unexampled grace Of these Ādityas and their aid to cherish life.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For not an enemy molests the paths which these Ādityas tread: Infallible guards, they strengthen us in happiness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now soon may Bhaga, Savitar, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman Give us the shelter widely spread which we implore.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Gods come thou whose fostering care none checks, O Goddesss Aditi: Come, dear to many, with the Lords who guard us well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For well these Sons of Aditi know to keep enmities aloof, Unrivalled, giving ample room, they save from woe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aditi guard our herd by day, Aditi, free from guile, by night, Aditi, ever strengthening, save us from grief!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And in the day our hymn is this: May Aditi come nigh to help, With loving-kindness bring us weal and chase our foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And may the Aśvins, the divine Pair of Physicians, send us health: May they remove iniquity and chase our foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Agni bless us with his fires, and Sūrya warm us pleasantly: May the pure Wind breathe sweet on us, and chase our foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drive ye disease and strife away, drive ye away malignity: Ādityas, keep us ever far from sore distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Remove from us the arrow, keep famine, Ādityas! far away: Keep enmities afar from us, Lords of all wealth!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, O Ādityas, grant to us the shelter that lets man go free, Yea, even the sinner from his sin, ye Bounteous Gods 1

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever mortal with the powe r of demons fain would injure us, May he, impetuous, suffer harm by his own deeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May sin o’ertake our human foe, the man who speaketh evil thing, Him who would cause our misery, whose heart is false.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gods, ye are with the simple ones, ye know each mortal in your hearts; Ye, Vasus, well discriminate the false and true.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fain would we have the sheltering aid of mountains and of water-floods: Keep far from us iniquity, O Heaven and Earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So with auspicious sheltering aid do ye, O Vasus, carry us Beyond all trouble and distress, borne in your ship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ādityas, ye Most Mighty Ones, grant to our children and their seed Extended term of life that they may live long days.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sacrifice, O Ādityas, is your inward monitor: be kind, For in the bond of kindred we are bound to you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts’ high protecting aid, the Aśvins, and the God who saves, Mitra and Varuṇa for weal we supplicate.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grant us a home with triple guard, Aryaman, Mitra, Varuṇa! Unthreatened, Maruts! meet for praise, and filled with men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And as we human beings, O Ādityas, are akin to death, Graciously lengthen ye our lives that we may live. Next: HYMN XIX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING praise to hiin, the Lord of Light. The Gods have made the God to be their messenger, And sent oblation to Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the Bounteous Giver, bright with varied flames, laud thou, O singer Sobhari- Him who controls this sacred food with Soma blent, who hath first claim to sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee have we chosen skilftillest in sacrifice, Immortal Priest among the Gods, Wise finisher of this holy rite:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Son of Strength, the blessed, brightly shining One, Agni whose light is excellent. May be by sacrifice win us in heaven the grace of Mitra, Varuṇa, and the Floods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mortal who hath ministered to Agni with oblation, fuel, ritual lore, And reverence, skilled in sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Verily swift to run are his fleet-footed steeds, and most resplendent fame is his. No trouble caused by Gods or wrought by mortal man from any side o’ertaketh him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we by thine own fires be well supplied with fire, O Son of Strength, O Lord of Might: Thou as our Friend hast worthy men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, who praises like a guest of friendly mind, is as a car that brings us gear. Also in thee is found perfect security thou art the Sovran Lord of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That man, moreover, merits praise who brings, auspicious Agni, sacrificial gifts May he win riches by his thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He for whose sacrifice thou standest up erect is prosperous and rules o’er men. He wins with coursers and with singers killed in song: with heroes he obtains the prize.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
