text: He in whose dwelling Agni is chief ornament, and, all-desired, loves his laud well, And zealously tends his offerings-

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His, or the lauding sage's word, his, Son of Strength! who Is most prompt with sacred gifts, Set thou beneath the Gods, Vasu, above mankind, the speech of the intelligent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who with sacrificial gifts or homage bringeth very skilful Agni nigh, Or him who flashes fast with song,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mortal who with blazing fuel, as his laws command, adores the Perfect God, Blest with his thoughts in splendour shall exceed all men, as though he overpassed the floods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us the splendour, Agni, which may overcome each greedy fiend in our abode, The wrath of evil-hearted folk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That, wherewith Mitra, Varuṇa, and Aryaman, the Aśvins, Bhaga give us light, That may we, by thy power finding best furtherance, worship, O Indra, helped by thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, most devout are they, the sages who have set thee Sage exceeding wise, O God, for men to look upon:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who have arranged thine altar Blessed God, at morn brought thine oblation, pressed the juice. They by their deeds of strength have won diem, mighty wealth, who have set all their hope in thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Agni worshipped bring us bliss, may the gift, Blessed One, and sacrifice bring bliss; Yea, may our praises bring us bliss.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Show forth the mind that brings success in war with fiends, wherewith thou conquerest in fight. Bring down the many firm hopes of our enemies, and let us vanquish with thine aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I praise with song the Friend of man, whom Gods sent down to be herald and messenger, Best worshipper, bearer of our gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou unto sharp-toothed Agni, Young and Radiant God, proclaimest with thy song the feast- Agni, who for our sweet strains moulds heroic strength when sacred oil is offered him,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: While, served with sacrificial oil, now upward and now downward Agni moves his sword, As doth the Asura his robe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The God, the Friend of man, who bears our gifts to heaven, the God with his sweet-smelling mouth, Distributes, skilled in sacrifice, his precious things, Invoking Priest, Immortal God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Son of Strength, Agni, if thou wert the mortal, bright as Mitra, I worshipped with our gifts! And I were the Immortal God

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I would not give thee up, Vasu, to calumny, or misery, O Bounteous One. My worshipper should feel no hunger or distress, nor, Agni, should he live in sin.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a son cherished in his father's houi§e, let our oblation rise unto the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With thine immediate aid may I, excellent Agni, ever gain my wish A mortal with a God to help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, by thy wisdom, by thy bounties, by thy leading may I gather wealth. Excellent Agni, thou art called my Providence: delight thou to be liberal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, he conquers by thine aid that brings him store of noble heroes and great strength, Whose bond of friendship is thy choice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy spark is black and crackling, kindled in due time, O Bounteous, it is taken up. Thou art the dear Friend of the mighty Mornings: thou shinest in glimmerings of the night.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We Sobharis have come to him, for succour, who is good to help with thousand powers, The Sovran, Trasadasyu's Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, thou on whom all other fires depend, as branches on the parent stem, I make the treasures of the folk, like songs, mine own, while I exalt thy sovran might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mortal whom, Ādityas, ye, Guilelew, lead to the farther bank Of all the princes, Bounteous Ones

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoe’er he be, Man-ruling Kings! the Regent of the race of men- May we, O Mitra, Varuṇa, and Aryaman, like him be furtherers of your law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A gift of fifty female slaves hath Trasadasyu given me, Purukutsa's son, Most liberal, kind, lord of the brave.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And Śyāva too for me led forth a strong steed at Suvastu's ford: A herd of three times seventy kine, good lord of gifts, he gave to me. Next: HYMN XX Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET none, Swift Travellers! check you: come hither, like-spirited, stay not far away, Ye benders even of what is firm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maruts, Ṛbhukṣans, Rudras come ye with your cars strong-fellied and exceeding bright. Come, ye for whom we long, with food, to sacrifice, come ye with love to Sobbari.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For well we know the vigorous might of Rudra's Sons, the Martits, who are passing strong, Swift Viṣṇu's band, who send the rain.,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Islands are bursting forth and misery is stayed: the heaven and earth are joined in one. Decked with bright rings, ye spread the broad expanses out, when ye, Self. luminous, stirred yourselves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even things immovable shake and reel, the mountains and the forest trees at your approach, And the earth trembles as ye come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To lend free course, O Maruts, to your furious rush, heaven high and higher still gives way, Where they, the Heroes mighty with their arms, display their gleaming omaments on their forms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: After their Godlike nature they, the bull. like Heroes, dazzling and impetuous, wear Great splendour as they show erect.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The pivot of the Sobharis' chariot within the golden box is balmed with milk. May they the Well-born, Mighty, kindred of the Cow, aid us to food and to delight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring, ye who sprinkle balmy drops. oblations to your vigorous Marut company, To those whose leader is the Bull.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, O ye Mares, on your stronghorsed car, solid in look, with solid naves. Lightly like winged falcons, O ye Heroes, come, come to enjoy our ofrerings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Their decoration is the same: their omaments of gold are bright upon their arms; Their lances glitter splendidly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They toil not to defend their bodies from attack, strong Heroes with their mighty arms. Strong are your bows and strong the weapons in your cars, and glory sits on every face.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose name extendeth like a sea, alone, resplendent, so that all have joy in it, And life-power like ancestral might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pay honour to these Maruts and sing praise to them, for of the wheel-spokes of the car Of these loud roarers none is last: this is their power, this moves them to give mighty gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Blest by your favouring help was he, O Maruts, at the earlier flushings of the morn, And even now shall he be blest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The strong man to whose sacrifice, O Heroes, ye approach that ye may taste thereof, With glories and with war that winneth spoil shall gain great bliss, ye Shakers of the world.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as Rudra's Sons, the brood of the Creator Dyaus, the Asura, desire, O Youthful Ones, so shall it be:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And these the bounteous, worthy of the Maruts who move onward pouring down the rain- Even for their sake, O Youthful Ones, with kindest heart take us to you to be your own.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Sobhari, with newest song sing out unto the youthful purifying Bulls, Even as a plougher to his steers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who, like a celebrated boxer, overcome the challengers in every fight: They who, like shining bulls, are most illustrious-honour those Maruts with thy song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Allied by common ancestry, ye Maruts, even the Cows, alike in energy, Lick, all by turns, each other's head.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even mortal man, ye Dancers breast adorned with gold, attains to brotherhood with you. Mark ye and notice us, O Maruts; evermore your friendship is secured to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, rich in noble gifts, bring us a portion of the Maruts’ medicine, Ye Coursers who are Friends to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Haters of those who serve you not, bliss-bringers, bring us bliss with those auspicious aids Wherewith ye are victorious and guard Sindhu well, and succour Krvi in his need.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maruts, who rest on fair trimmed grass, what balm soever Sindhu or Asikni hath, Or mountains or the seas contain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye carry on your bodies, ye who see it all: so bless us graciously therewith. Cast, Maruts, to the ground our sick man's malady: replace the dislocated limb. Next: HYMN XXI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE call on thee, O Matchless One! We seeking help, possessing nothing firm ourselves, Call on thee wonderful in fight

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On thee for aid in sacrifice. This youth of ours, the bold, the mighty, hath gonse forth. We therefore, we thy friends, Indra, havie chosen thee, free-giver, as our Guardian God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, for the drops are here, O Lord of corn-lands. Lord of horses, Lord of kine: Drink thou the Soma, Soma's Lord!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For we the kinless singers have drawn hither thee, O Indra, who hast numerous kin. With all the forms thou hast, comic thou of bull-like strength, come near to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sitting like birds beside thy meath., mingled with milk, that gladdeneth and exalteth thee, Indra, to thee we sing aloud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We speak to thee with this our reverential prayer. Why art thou pondering yet awhile? Here are our wishes; thou art liberal, Lord of Bays: we and our hymns are present here.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For not in recent times alone, O Indra, Thunder-armed, have we obtained thine aid. Of old we knew thy plenteous wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hero, we knew thy friendship and thy rich rewards: these, Thunderer, now we crave of thee. O Vasu, for all wealth that cometh of the kine, sharpen our powers, fair-visored God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who of old hath brought to us this and that blessing, him I magnify for you, Even Indra, O my friends, for help

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Borne by Bay Steeds, the Lord of heroes, ruling men, for it is he who takes; delight. May Maghavan bestow on us his worshippers hundreds of cattle and of steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hero, may we, with thee for Friend, withstand the man who pants against us in his wrath, In fight with people rich in kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we be victors in the singer's battlesong, and meet the wicked, Much invoked! With heroes smite the foeman and show forth our strength. O Indra, further thou our thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, from all ancient time rivalless ever and companionless art thou: Thou seekest comradeship in war.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou findest not the wealthy man to be thy friend: those scorn thee who are flown with wine. What time thou thunderest and gatherest, then thou, even as a Father, art invoked.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, let us not, like fools who waste their lives at home, with friendship such as thine Sit idly by the poured-out juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Giver of kine, may we not miss thy gracious gifts: let us not rob thee of thine own. Strip even the strong places of the foe, and bring: thy gifts can never be made vain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra or blest Sarasvatī alone bestows such wealth, treasure so great, or thou, O Citra, on the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Citra is King, and only kinglings are the rest who dwell beside Sarasvatī. He, like Parjanya with his rain, hath spread himself with thousand, yea, with myriad gifts. Next: HYMN XXII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HITHERWARD have I called to-day, for succour, that most wondrous car Which ye ascended, Aśvins, ye whose paths are red, swift to give Car, for Sūrya's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Car ever young, much longed-for, easily invoked, soon guided, first in deeds of might, Which waits and serves, O Sobhari, with benevolence, without a rival or a foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Aśvins with our homage, these Two Omnipresent Deities Hitherward will we bring for kind help, these who seek the dwelling of the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One of your chariot wheels is moving swiftly round, one speeds for you its onward course. Like a milch-cow, O Lords of splendour, and with haste let your benevolence come to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That chariot of yours which hath a triple seat and reins of gold, The famous car that traverseth the heaven and earth, thereon Nāsatyas, Aśvins, come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye with your plough, when favouring Manu with your help, ploughed the first harvest in the sky. As such will we exalt you, Lords of splendour, now, O Aśvins, with our prayer and praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us, Lords of ample wealth, by paths of everlasting Law, Whereby to high dominion ye with mighty strength raised Trksi, Trasadasyu's son.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma pressed with stones is yours, ye Heroes, Lords of plenteous wealth. Approach to drink the Soma, come, drink in the worshipper's abode.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, mount the chariot, mount the golden seat, ye who are Lords of plenteous wealth, And bring to us abundant food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The aids wherewith ye helped Paktha and Adhrigt;, and Babhru severed from his friends,— With those, O Aśvins, come hither with speed and soon, and heal whatever is diseased.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When we continually invoke the Aśvins, the resistless, at this time of day, We lovers of the song, with songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through these, ye Mighty Ones, come hither to my call which brings all blessings, wears all forms,— Tlirough which, All-present Heroes, lavishest of food ye strengthened Krvi, come through these.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I speak to both of these as such, these Aśvins whom I reverence at this time of day: With homage we entreat them both.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye who are Lords of splendour, ye whose paths are red, at eve, at mom, at sacrifice, Give us not utterly as prey to mortal foe, ye Rudras, Lords of ample wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For bliss I call. the blissful car, at morn the inseparable Aśvins with their car I call, like Sobhari our sire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rapid as thought, and strong, and speeding to thejoy, bringing.your swiftly-coming help, Be to us a protection even from far away Lords of great wealth, with many aids.'

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Wonder-Workers, to our home, our home, O Aśvins, rich in cattle, steeds, and gold, Chief drinkers of the Soma's juice

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Choice-worthy strength, heroic, firm and excellent, uninjured by the Rakṣas foe, At this your coming nigh, ye Lords of ample wealth and all good things, may we obtain. Next: HYMN XXIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WORSHIP thou Jātavedas, pray to him who willingly accepts, Whose smoke wanders at will, and none may grasp his flame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, all men's friend, Visvamanas, exaltest Agni with thy song, The Giver, and his flames with which no cars contend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose resolute assault, to win vigour and food, deserves our praise,— Through whose discovering power the priest obtaineth wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Up springs the imperishable flame, the flame of the Refulgent One Most bright, with glowing jaws and glory in his train.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Skilled in fair sacrifice, extolled, arise in Godlike loveliness, Shining with lofty splendour, with effulgent light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Called straight to our oblations, come, O Agni, through our eulogies, As thou hast been our envoy bearing up our gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I call your Agni, from of old Invoking Priest of living men: Him with this song I laud and magnify for you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom, wondrous wise, they animate with solemn rites and his fair form, Kind as a friend to men who keep the holy Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, true to Law, who perfecteth the sacrifice,. Law-loving ones! Ye with your song have gratified in the place of prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May all our sacrifices go to him the truest Aṅgiras, Who is among mankind the most illustrious Priest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Imperishable Agni, thine are all these high enkindled lights, Like horses and like stallions showing forth their strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So give us, Lord of Power and Might, riches combined with hero strength, And guard us with our sons and grand. sons in our frays.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soon as the eager Lord of men is friendly unto Manti's race, Agni averteth from us all the demon host.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Hero Agni, Lord of men, on hearing this new laud of mine, Burn down the Rākṣasas, enchanters, with thy flame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No mortal foe can e’er prevail by arts of magic over him Who serveth Agni well with sacrificial gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Vyaśva the sage, who sought the Bull, hath won thee, finder of good things: As such may we enkindle thee for ample wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Uśanā Kāvya stablished thee, O Agni, as Invoking Priest: Thee, Jātavedas, Sacrificing Priest for man.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All Deities of one accord appointed thee their messenger: Thou, God, through hearing, hadst first claim to sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him may the mortal hero make his own immortal messenger. Far-spreading, Purifier, him whose path is black.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With lifted ladles let us call him splendid with his brilliant flame, Men's ancient Agni, wasting not, adorable.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man who pays the worship due to him with sacrificial gifts Obtains both plenteous nourishment and hero fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Jātavedas Agni, chief in sacrifices, first of all With homage goes the ladle rich with sacred gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as Vyatya did, may we with these most high and liberal hymns Pay worship unto Agni of the splendid flame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now sing, as Sthurayupa sang, with lands to him who spreadeth far, To Agni of the home, O Ṛṣi, Vyaśva's son.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As welcome guest of human kind, as offspring of the forest kings, The sages worship ancient Agni for his aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For men's oblations brought to him who is the mighty Lord of all, Sit, Agni, mid our homage, on the sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Grant us abundant. treasures, grant the opulence which many crave, With store of heroes, progeny, and high renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, Most Youthful of the Gods, send evermore the gift of wealth Unto Varosusaman and to all his folk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A mighty Conqueror art thou, O Agni, so disclose to us Food in our herds of kine and gain of ample wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Agni, art a glorious God: bring hither Mitra, Varuṇa, Imperial Sovrans, holy-minded, true to Law. Next: HYMN XXIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: COMPANIONS, let us learn a prayer to Indra. whom the thunder arms, To glorify your bold and most heroic Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou by slaying Vṛtra art the Vṛtra-slayer, famed for might. Thou, Hero, in rich gifts surpassest wealthy chiefs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, when glorified, bring us riches of very wondrous fame, Set in the highest rank, Wealth-giver, Lord of Bays!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, Indra, thou disclosest that preeminent dear wealth of men: Boldly, O Bold One, glorified, bring it to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The workers of destruction stay neither thy right hand nor thy left: Nor hosts that press about thee, Lord of Bays, in fight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Thunder-armed, I come with songs to thee as to a stall with kine: Fulfil the wish and thought of him who sings thy praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Chief Vṛtra-slayer, through the hymn of Visvamanas think of all, All that concerneth us, Excellent, Mighty Guide.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we, O Vṛtra-slayer, O Hero, find this thy newest boon, Longed-for, and excellent, thou who art much invoked!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Dancer, Much-invoked! as thy great power is unsurpassed, So be thy bounty to the worshipper unchecked.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most Mighty, most heroic One, for mighty bounty fill thee full. Though strong, strengthen thyself to win wealth, Maghavan!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Thunderer, never have our prayers gone forth to any God but thee: So help us, Maghavan, with thine assistance now.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Dancer, verily I find none else for bounty, saving thee, For splendid wealth and power, thou Lover of the Song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra pour ye out the drops meath blent with Soma let him drink With bounty and with majesty will he further us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I spake to the Bay Coursers' Lord, to him who gives ability: Now hear the son of Asva as he praises thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Never was any Hero born before thee mightier than thou: None certairdy like thee in goodness and in wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O ministering priest, pour out of the sweet juice what gladdens most: So is the Hero praised who ever prospers us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, whom Tawny Coursers bear, praise such as thine, preeminent, None by his power or by his goodness hath attained.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We, seeking glory, have invoked this Master of all power and might Who must be glorified by constant sacri fice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, sing we praise to Indra, friends, the Hero who deserves the laud, Him who with none to aid o’ercomes all tribes of men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him who wins the kine, who keeps no cattle back, Celestial God, Speak wondrous speech more sweet than butter and than meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose hero powers are measureless, whose bounty ne’er may be surpassed, Whose liberality, like light, is over all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Vyaśva did, praise Indra, praise the Strong unfluctuating Guide, Who gives the foe's possessions to the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, son of Vyaśva, praise thou him who to the tenth time still is new, The very Wise, whom living men must glorify

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou knowest, Indra, Thunder-armed, how to avoid destructive powers, As one secure from pitfalls each returning day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, bring that aid wherewith of old, Most Wondrous! thou didst slay His foes for active Kutsa: send it down to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So now we seek thee fresh in might, Most Wonderful in act! for gain: For thou art he who conquers all our foes for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who will set free from ruinous woe, or Ārya on the Seven Streams: O valiant Hero, bend the Dāsa's weapon down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As to Varosusaman thou broughtest great riches, for their gain, To Vyaśva's sons, Blest Lady, rich in ample wealth!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let Narya's sacrificial meed reach Vyaśva's Soma-bearing sons: In hundreds and in thousands be the great reward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If one should ask thee, Where is he who sacrificed? Whither lookest thou? Like Vala he hath passed away and dwelleth now on Gomati. Next: HYMN XXV. Mitra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I WORSHIP you who guard this All, Gods, holiest among the Gods, You, faithful to the Law, whose power is sanctified.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, too, like charioteers are they, Mitra and sapient Varuṇa, Sons high-born from of old, whose holy laws stand fast.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Twain, possessors of all wealth, most glorious, for supremest sway Aditi, Mighty Mother, true to Law, brought forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Great Varuṇa and Mitra, Gods, Asuras and imperial Lords, True to Eternal Law proclaim the high decree.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The offspring of a lofty Power, Dakṣa's Two Sons exceeding strong, Who, Lords of flowing rain, dwell in the place of food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye who have gathered up your gifts, celestial and terrestrial food, Let your rain come to us fraught with the mist of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Twain, who from the lofty sky seem to look down on herds below, Holy, imperial Lords, are set to be revered.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They, true to Law, exceeding strong, have sat them down for savran rule: Princes whose laws stand fast, they have obtained their sway.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pathfinders even better than the eye, with unobstructed sight, Even when they close their lids, observant, they perceive.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may the Goddess Aditi, may the Nāsatyas guard us well, The Martits guard us well,.endowed with mighty strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do ye, O Bounteous Gods, protect our dwelling lace by day and night: With you for our defenders may we go unharmed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we, unharmed, serve bountiful Viṣṇu, the God who slayeth none: Self-moving Sindhu hear and be the first to mark.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This sure protection we elect, desirable and reaching far, Which Mitra, Varuṇa, and Aryaman afford.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And may the Sindhu of the floods, the Maruts, and the ASvin Pair, Boon Indra, and boon Viṣṇu have one mind with us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Because these warring Heroes stay the enmity of every foe, As the fierce water-flood repels the furious ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here this one God, the Lord of men, looks forth exceeding far and wide: And we, for your advantage, keep his holy laws.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We keep the old accustomed laws, the statutes of supremacy, The Iong-known laws of Mitra and of Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who hath measured with his ray the boundaries of heaven and earth, And with his majesty hath filled the two worlds full,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sūrya hath spread his light aloft up to the region of the sky, Like Agni all aflame when gifts are offered him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With him who sits afar the word is lord of food that comes from kine, Controller of the gift of unempoisoned food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So unto Sūrya, Heaven, and Earth at morning and at eve I speak. Bringing enjoyments ever rise thou up for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From Uksanyayana a bay, from Harayana a white steed, And from Susaman we obtained a hamessed car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These two shall bring me further gain of troops of tawny-coloured steeds, The carriers shall they be of active men of war.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And the two sages have I gained who hold the reins and bear the whip, And the two great strong coursers, with my newest song. Next: HYMN XXVI. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I CALL your chariot to receive united praise mid princely men, Strong Gods who pour down wealth, of never vanquished might!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye to Varosusaman come, Nāsatyas, for this glorious rite. With your protecting aid. Strong Gods, who pour down wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So with oblations we invoke you, rich in ample wealth, to-day, When night hath passed, O ye who send us plenteous food. O Aśvins, Heroes, let your car, famed, best to travel, come to us, And, for his glory, mark your zealous servant's lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, who send us precious gifts, even when offended, think of him: For ye, O Rudras, lead us safe beyond our foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Wonder-Workers, with fleet steeds ye fly completely round this All, Stirring our thoughts, ye Lords of splendour, honey-hued.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all-sustaining opulence, Aśvins, come hitherward to us, Ye rich and noble Heroes, ne’er to be o’erthrown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To welcome this mine offering, O ye Indra-like Nāsatyas, come As Gods of best accord this day with other Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For we, like Vyaśva, lifting up our voice like oxen, call on you: With all your loving kindness, Sages, come to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Ṛṣi, laud the Aśvins well. Will they not listen to thy call? Will they not burn the Paṇis who are nearer them?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Heroes, listen to the son of Vyaśva, and regard me here, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, of one accord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gods whom we yearn for, of your gifts, of what ye bring to us, bestow By princes' hands on me, ye Mighty, day by day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him whom your sacrifices clothe, even as a woman with her robe, The Aśvins help to glory honouring him well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoso regards your care of men as succour widest in its reach, About his dwelling go, ye Aśvins, loving us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us ye who pour down wealth, come to the home which men must guard: Like shafts, ye are made meet for sacrifice by song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most fetching of all calls, the laud, as envoy, Heroes, called to you Be it your own, O Aśvin Pair.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be ye in yonder sea of heaven, or joying in the home of food, Listen to me, Immortal Ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This river with his lucid flow attracts you, more than all the streams,— Even Sindhu with his path of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, with that glorious fame come hither, through our brilliant song, Come ye whose ways are marked with light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Harness the steeds who draw the car, O Vasu, bring the well-fed pair. O Vāyu, drink thou of our meath: come unto our drink-offerings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wonderful Vāyu, Lord of Right, thou who art Tvaṣṭar's son-in-law, Thy saving succour we elect.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Tvaṣṭar's son-in-law we pray for wealth whereof he hath control: For glory we seek vayu, men with juice effused.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From heaven, auspicious Vāyu, come drive hither with thy noble steeds: Come on thy mighty car with wide-extending seat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call thee to the homes of men, thee wealthiest in noble food, And liberal as a press-stone with a horse's back.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, glad and joyful in thine heart, do thou, God, Vāyu, first of all Vouchsafe us water, strength, and thought. Next: HYMN XXVII. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: CHEIF Priest is Agni at the laud, as stones and grass at sacrifice: With song I seek the Maruts, Brahmaṇaspati, Gods for help much to be desired.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I sing to cattle and to Earth, to trees, to Dawns, to Night, to plants. O all ye Vasus, ye possessors of all wealth, be ye the furtherers of our thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Forth go, with Agni, to the Gods our sacrifice of ancient use, To the Ādityas, Varuṇa whose Law stands fast, and the all-lightening Marut troop.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lords of all wealth, may they be strengtheners of man, destroyers of his enemies. Lords of all wealth, do ye, with guards which none may harm, preserve our dwelling free from foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us with one mind to-day, come to us all with one accord, Maruts with holy song, and, Goddess Aditi, Mighty One, to our house and home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send us delightful things, ye Maruts, on your steeds: come ye, O Mitra, to our gifts. Let Indra, Varuṇa, and the Ādityas sit, swift Heroes, on our sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We who have trimmed the grass for you, and set the banquet in array, And pressed the Soma, call you, Varuina, like men, with sacrificial fires aflame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Maruts, Visinu, Aśvins, Pūṣan, haste away with minds turned hitherward to Me. Let the Strong Indra, famed as Vṛtra's slayer, come first with the winners of the spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Guileless Gods, bestow on us a refuge strong on every side, A sure protection, Vasus, unassailable from near at hand or from afar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kinship have I with you, and close alliance O ye Gods, destroyers of our foes. Call us to our prosperity of former days, and soon to new klicity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For now have I sent forth to you, that I may win a fair reward, Lords of all wealth, with homage, this my song of praise. like a milch-cow that faileth not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Excellent Savitar hath mounted up on high for you, ye sure and careful Guides. Bipeds and quadrupeds, with several hopes and aims, and birds have settled to their tasks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Singing their praise with God-like thought let us invoke each God for grace, Each God to bring you help, each God to strengthen you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For of one spirit are the Gods with mortal man, co-sharers all of gracious gifts. May they increase our strength hereafter and to-day, providing case and ample room.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I laud you, O ye Guileless Gods, here where we meet to render praise. None, Varuṇa and Mitra, harins the mortal, man who honours and obeys your laws.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He makes his house endure, he gathers plenteous food who pays obedience to your will. Born in his sons anew he spreads as Law commands, and prospers every way unharmed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: E’en without war he gathers wealth, and goes hisway on pleasant paths, Whom Mitra, Varuṇa and Aryaman protect, sharing the gift,of one accord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: E’en on the plain for him ye make a sloping path, an easy way where road is none: And far away from him the ineffectual shaft must vanish, shot at him in vain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If ye appoint the rite to-day, kind Rulers, when the Sun ascends, Lords of all wealth, at sunset or at wakingtime, or be it at the noon of day,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Or, Asuras, when ye have sheltered the worshipper who goes to sacrifice, at eve may we, O Vasus, ye possessors of all wealth, come then into the midst of You.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If ye to-day at sunrise, or at noon, or in the gloom of eve, Lords of all riches, give fair treasure to the man, the wise man who hath sacrificed,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then we, imperial Rulers, claim of you this boon, your wide protection, as a son. May we, Ādityas, offering holy gifts, obtain that which shall bring us greater bliss. Next: HYMN XXVIII. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE Thirty Gods and Three besides, whose seat hath been the sacred grass, From time of old have found and gained.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, Agnis, with Consorts, sending boons, To whom our Vaṣaṭ! is addressed:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These are our guardians in the west, and northward here, and in the south, And on the cast, with all the tribe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as the Gods desire so verily shall it be. None minisheth this power of theirs, No demon, and no mortal

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Seven carry seven spears; seven are the splendours they possess, And seven the glories they assume. Next: HYMN XXIX Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ONE is a youth brown, active, manifold he decks the golden one with ornament.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Another, luminous, occupies the place of sacritice, Sage, among the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One brandishes in his hand an iron knife, firm, in his seat amid the Deities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Another holds the thunderbolt, wherewith he slays the Vṛtras, resting in his hand.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Another bears a pointed weapon: bright is he, and strong, with healing medicines.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Another, thief-like, watches well the ways, and knows the places where the treasures lie.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Another with his mighty stride hath made his three steps thither where the Gods rejoice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Two with one Dame ride on with winged steeds, and journey forth like travellers on their way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Two, highest, in the heavens have set their seat, worshipped with holy oil, imperial Kings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Some, singing lauds, conceived the Sāma-hymn, great hymn whereby they caused the Sun to shine. Next: HYMN XXX. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: NOT one of you, ye Gods, is small, none of you is a feeble child: All of you, verily, are great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus be ye lauded, ye destroyers of the foe, ye Three-and-Thirty Deities, The Gods of man, the Holy Ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such defend and succour us, with benedictions speak to us: Lead us not from our fathers' and from Manu's path into the distance far away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Deities who stay with us, and all ye Gods of all mankind, Give us your wide protection, give shelter for cattle and for steed. Next: HYMN XXXI. Various Deities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THAT Brahman pleases Indra well, who worships, sacrifices, pours Libation, and prepares the meal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Śakra protects from woe the man who gives him sacrificial cake. And offers Soma blent with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His chariot shall be glorious, sped by Gods, and mighty shall he be, Subduing all hostilities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Each day that passes, in his house flows his libation, rich in milk, Exhaustless, bringing progeny.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Gods, with constant draught of milk, husband and wife with one accord Press out and wash the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They gain sufficient food: they come united to the sacred grass, And never do they fail in strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Never do they deny or seek to hide the favour of the Gods: They win high glory for themselves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With sons and daughters by their side they reach their full extent of life, Both decked with ornaments of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Serving the Immortal One with gifts of sacrificial meal and wealth, They satisfy the claims of love and pay due honour to the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We claim protection from the Hills, we claim protection of the Floods, Of him who stands by Viṣṇu's side.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Pūṣan come, and Bhaga, Lord of wealth, All-bounteous, for our weal Broad be the path that leads to bliss:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aramati, and, free from foes, Visva with spirit of a God, And the Ādityas’ peerless might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seeing that Mitra, Aryaman, and Varuṇa are guarding us, The paths of Law are fair to tread.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I glorify with song, for wealth, Agni the God, the first of you. We honour as a well-loved Friend the God who prospereth our fields.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As in all frays the hero, so swift moves his car whom Gods attend. The man who, sacrificing, strives to win the heart of Deities will conquer those who worship not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ne’er are ye injured, worshipper, presser of juice, or pious man. The man who, sacrificing, strives to win the heart of Deities will conquer those who worship not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: None in his action equals him, none holds him far or keeps him off. The man who, sacrificing, strives to win the heart of Deities will conquer those who worship not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Such strength of heroes shall be his, such mastery of fleet-foot steeds. The man who, sacrificing, strives to win the heart of Deities will conquer those who worship not. Next: HYMN XXXII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: KANVAS, tell forth with song the deeds of Indra, the Impetuous, Wrought in the Soma's wild delight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong God, he slew Anarsani, Srbinda, Pipru, and the fiend, Ahīśuva, and loosed the floods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou broughtest down the dwelling-place, the height of lofty Arbuda. That exploit, Indra, must be famed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bold, to your famous Soma I call the fair-visored God for aid, Down like a torrent from the hill.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rejoicing in the Soma-draughts, Hero, burst open, like a fort, The stall of horses and of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If my libation gladdens, if thou takest pleasure in my laud, Come with thy Godhead from afar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Lover of the Song, the singers of thy praise are we: O Soma-drinker, quicken us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, taking thy delight with us bring us still undiminished food: Great is thy wealth, O Maghavan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make thou us rich in herds of kine, in steeds, in gold: let us exert Our strength in sacrificial gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us call him to aid whose hands stretch far, to whom high laud is due. Who worketh well to succour us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, Śatakratu, even in fight acts as a Vṛtra-slayer s,till: He gives his worshippers much wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May he, this A;akra, strengthen us, Boon God who satisfies our needs, Indra, with all lhis saving helps.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him, the mighty stream of wealth, the Soma-presser's rescuing Friend, To Indra sing your song of praise;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who bringeth what is great and firm, who winneth glory in his wars, Lord of vast wealth through power and might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: There liveth none to cheek or stay his energies and gracious deeds: None who can say, He giveth not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No debt is due by Brahmans now, by active men who press the juice: Well hath each Soma-draught been paid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing ye to him who must be praised, say lauds to him who must be praised, Bring prayer to him who must be praised.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May be, unchecked, strong, meet for praise, bring hundreds, thousands forth to light, Indra who aids the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Go with thy God-like nature forth, go where the folk are calling thee: Drink, Indra, of the drops we pour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink milky draughts which are thine own, this too which was with Tugrya once, This is it, Indra, that is thine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pass him who psours libations out in angry mood or after sin: Here drink the juice we offer thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Over the three great distances, past the Five Peoples go thy way, O Indra, noticing our voice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send forth thy ray like Sūrya: let my songs attract thee hitherward, Like waters gathering to the vale.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now to the Hero fair of cheek, Adhvaryu, pour the Soma forth: Bring of the juice that he may drink

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who cleft the water-cloud in twain, loosed rivers for their downward flow, And set the ripe milk in the kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, meet for praise, slew Vṛtra, slew Ahīśuva, Urnavabha's son, And pierced th:rough Arbuda with frost.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him your matchless Mighty One, unconquerable Conqueror, Sing forth the prayer which Gods have given:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, who in the wild delight of Soma juice considers here All holy Laws among the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither let these thy Bays who share thy banquet, Steeds with golden manes, Convey thee to the feast prepared.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither, O thou whom many laud, the Bays whom Priyamedha praised, Shall bring thee to the Soma-draught. Next: HYMN XXXIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE compass thee like waters, we whose grass is trimmed and Soma pressed. Here where the filter pours its stream, thy worshippers round thee, O Vṛtra-slayer, sit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men, Vasu! by the Soma, with lauds call thee to the foremost place: When comest thou athirst unto the juice as home, O Indra, like a bellowing bull?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Boldly, Bold Hero, bring us spoil in thousands for the Kaṇvas' sake. O active Maghavan, with eager prayer we crave the yellow-hued with store ol kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Medhyātithi, to Indra sing, drink of the juice to make thee glad. Close-knit to his Bay Steeds, bolt-armed, beside the juice is he: his chariot is of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He Who is praised as strong of hand both right and left, most wise and hold: Indra who, rich in hundreds, gathers thousands up, honoured as breaker-down of forts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The bold of heart whom none provokes, who stands in bearded confidence; Much-lauded, very glorious, overthrowing foes, strong Helper, like a bull with might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who knows what vital ower he wins, drinking beside the flowing juice? This is the fair-checked God who, joying in the draught, breaks down the castles in his strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As a wild elephant rushes on this way and that way, mad with heat,' None may compel thee, yet come hither to the draught: thou movest mighty in thy power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When he, the Mighty, ne’er o’erthrown, steadfast, made ready for the fight, When Indra Maghavan lists to his praiser's call, he will not stand aloof, but come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, verily, thou art a Bull, with a bull's rush. whom none may stay: Thou Mighty One, art celebrated as a Bull, famed as a Bull both near and far.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy reins are very bulls in strength, bulls' strength is in thy golden whip. Thy car, O Maghavan, thy Bays are strong as bulls: thou, Śatakratu, art a Bull.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the strong presser press for thee. Bring hither, thou straight-rushing Bull. The mighty makes the mighty run in flowing streams for thee whom thy Bay Horses bear.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, thou most potent Indra, come to drink the savoury Soma juice. Maghavan, very wise, will quickly come to hear the songs, the prayer, the hymns of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thou hast mounted on thy car let thy yoked Bay Steeds carry thee, Past other men's libations, Lord of Hundred Powers, thee, Vṛtra-slayer, thee our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O thou Most Lofty One, accept our laud as nearest to thine heart. May our libations be most sweet to make thee glad, O Soma-drinker, Heavenly Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Neither in thy decree nor mine, but in another's he delights,— The man who brought us unto this.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra himself hath said, The mind of woman brooks not discipline, Her intellect hath little weight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His pair of horses, rushing on in their wild transport, draw his car: High-lifted is the stallion's yoke.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cast down thine eyes and look not up. More closely set thy feet. Let none See what thy garment veils, for thou, a Brahman, hast become a dame. Next: HYMN XXXIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, Indra, with thy Bays, come thou to Kaṇva's eulogy. Ye by command of yonder Dyaus, God bright by day! have gone to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the stone draw thee as it speaks, the Soma-stone with ringing voice. Ye by command of yonder Dyaus, God bright by day! have gone to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The stones' rim shakes the Soma here like a wolf worrying a sheep. Ye by command of yonder Dyaus, God bright by day! have gone to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Kaṇvas call thee hitherward for succour and to win the spoil. Ye by command of yonder Dyaus, God bright by day! have gone to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I set for thee, as for the Strong, the first draught of the juices shed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come with abundant blessings, come with perfect care to succour us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Lord of lofty thought, who hast infinite wealth and countless aids.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Adorable mid Gods, the Priest good to mankind shall bring thee near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As wings the falcon, so thy Bays rushing in joy shall carry thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come from the enemy to us, to svaha and the Soma-draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither with thine car inclined to hear, take pleasure in our lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of well-nourished Horses, come with well-fed Steeds alike in hue.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither from the mountains, come from regions of the sea of air.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Disclose to us O Hero, wealth in thousands both of kine and steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring riches hitherward to us in hundreds, thousands, myriads. Ye by command of yonder Dyaus, God bright by day! have gone to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The thousand steeds, the mightiest troop, which we and Indra have received From Vasurocis as a gift,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The brown that match the wind in speed, and bright bay coursers fleet of foot, Like Suns, resplendent are they all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mid the Pargvata's rich gifts, swift steeds whose wheels run rapidly, I seemed to stand amid a wood. Next: HYMN XXXV. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH Agni and with Indra, Viṣṇu. Varuṇa, with the Ādityas, Rudras, Vasus, closely leagued; Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all the Holy Thoughts, all being Mighty Ones! in close alliance wil the Mountains, Heaven, and Earth; Accordant. of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all the Deities, three times eleven, here, in close alliance with the Maruts, Bhṛgus, Floods; Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept the sacrifice, attend to this my call: come nigh, O ye Twain Gods, to all libations here. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, bring us strengthening food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept our praise-song as a youth accepts a maid. Come nigh, O ye Twain Gods, to all libations here. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, bring us strengthening food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept the songs we sing, accept the solemn rite. Come nigh, O ye Twain Gods, to all libations here. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, bring us strengthening food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye fly as starlings fly unto the forest trees; like buffaloes ye seek the Soma we have shed. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, come thrice, O Aśvins, to our home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye fly like swans, like those who travel on their way; like buffaloes ye seek the Soma we have shed. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, come thrice, O Aśvins, to our home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye fly to our oblation like a pair of hawks; like buffaloes ye seek the Soma we have shed. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, come thrice, O Aśvins, to our home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hitherward and drink and satisfy yourselves, bestow upon us progeny and affluence. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, grant us vigorous strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Conquer your foes, protect us, praise your worshippers; bestow upon us progeny and affluence. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, grant us vigorous strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slay enemies, animate men whom ye befriend; bestow upon us progeny and affluence. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, O Aśvins, grant us vigorous strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Mitra, Varuṇa, Dharma, and the Maruts in your company approach unto your praiser's call. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, and with the Ādityas, Aśvins! come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Viṣṇu and the Aṅgirases attending you, and with the Maruts come unto your praiser's call. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, and with the Ādityas, Aśvins! come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Ṛbhus and With Vājas. O ye Mighty Ones, leagued with the Maruts come ye to your praiser's call. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, and with the Ādityas, Aśvins! come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give spirit to our prayer and animate our thoughts; slay ye the Rākṣasas and drive away disease. Accordant, of One mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, -the presser's Soma, Aśvins drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strengthen the Ruling Power, strengthen the men of war; slay ye the Rākṣasas and drive away disease. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, the presser's Soma, Aśvins drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give strength unto the milch-kine, give the people strength, slay ye the Rākṣasas and drive away disease. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, the presser's Soma, Aśvins drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As ye heard Atri's earliest eulogy, so hear Śyāvāśva, Soma-presser, ye who reel in joy. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, drink juice, O Aśvins, three days old.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Further like running streams Śyāvāśva's eulogies who presses out the Soma, ye who reel in joy. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, drink juice, O Aśvins, three days old.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seize, as ye grasp the reins, Śyāvāśva's solemn rites who presses out the Soma, ye who reel in joy. Accordant, of one mind with Sūrya and with Dawn, drink juice, O Aśvins, three days old.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drive down your chariot hitherward drink ye the Soma's savoury juice. Approach, ye Aśvins, come to us: I call you, eager for your aid. Grant treasures to the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When sacrifice which tells our reverence hath begun. Heroes! to drink the gushing juice, Approach, ye Aśvins, come to us: I call you, eager for your aid. Grant treasures to the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sate you with consecrated drink, with juice effused, ye Deities. Approach, ye Aśvins, come to us: I call you, eager for your aid. Grant treasures to the worshipper. Next: HYMN XXXVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOU helpest him whose grass is trimmed, who sheds the juice, O Śatakratu, drink Soma to make thee glad. The share which they have fixed for thee, thou, Indra, Victor o’er all hosts and space, begirt with Maruts, Lord of Heroes, winner of the floods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Maghavan, help thy worshipper: let him help thee. O Śatakratu, drink Soma to make thee glad. The share which they have fixed for thee, etc.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou aidest Gods with food, and that with might aids thee, O Śatakratu, drink Soma to make thee glad.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Creator of the heaven, creator of the earth, O Śatakratu, drink Soma to make thee glad.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Father of cattle, father of all steeds art thou. O Śatakratu, drink Soma to make thee glad.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Stone-hurler, glorify the Atris' hymn of praise. O Śatakratu, drink Soma to make thee glad.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hear thou Śyāvāśva while he pours to thee, as erst thou heardest Atri when he wrought his holy rites. Indra, thou only gavest Trasadasyu aid in the fierce fight with heroes, strengthening his prayers. Next: HYMN XXXVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THIS prayer, and those who shed the juice, in wars with Vṛtra thou holpest, Indra, Lord of Strength, with all thy succours. O Vṛtra-slayer, from libation poured at noon, drink of the Soma juice, thou blameless Thunderer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou mighty Conqueror of hostile armaments, O Indra, Lord of Strength, with all thy saving help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sole Ruler, thou art Sovran of this world of life, O Indra, Lord of Strength, with all thy saving help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou only sunderest these two consistent worlds, O Indra, Lord of Strength, with all thy saving help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art the Lord supreme o’er rest and energy, O Indra, Lord of Strength, with all thy saving help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou helpest one to power, and one thou hast not helped, O Indra, Lord of Strength, with all thy saving aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hear thou Śyāvāśva while he sings to thee, as erst thou heardest Atri when he wrought his holy rites. Indra, thou only gavest Trasadasyu aid in the fierce fight with heroes, strengthening his powers. Next: HYMN XXXVIII. Indra-Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YE Twain are Priests of sacrifice, winners in war and holy works: Indra and Agni, mark this well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye bounteous riders on the car, ye Vṛtra-slayers unsubdued: Indra and Agni, mark this well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men with pressing-stones have pressed this meath of yours which gives delight: Indra, and Agni, mark this well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept our sacrifice for weal, sharers of praise! the Soma shed: Indra and Agni, Heroes, come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be pleased with these libations which attract you to our sacred gifts Indra and Agni, Heroes, come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept this eulogy of mine whose model is the Gāyatrī: Indra and Agni, Heroes, Come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come with the early-faring Gods, ye who are Lords of genuine wealth: Indra-Agni, to the Soma-draught

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hear ye the call of Atris, hear Śyāvāśva as he sheds the juice: Indra-Agni to the Soma-draught

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus have I called you to our aid as sages called on you of old: Indra-Agni to the Soma draught!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra's and Agni's grace I claim, Sarasvatī's associates To whom this psalm of praise is sung. Next: HYMN XXXIX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE glorious Agni have I praised, and worshipped with. the sacred food. May Agni deck the Gods for us. Between both gathering-places he goes on his embassy, the Sage. May all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, burn down the word within their bodies through our newest speech, All hatreds of the godless, all the wicked man's malignities. Away let the destroyers go. May all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, I offer hymns to thee, like holy oil within thy mouth. Acknowledge them. among the Gods, for thou art the most excellent, the worshipper's blissful messenger. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni bestows all vital power even as each man supplicates. He brings the Vasus strengthening gifts, and grants delight, in rest and stir, for every calling on the Gods. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni hath made himself renowned by wonderful victorious act. He is the Priest of all the tribes, chosen with sacrificial meeds. He urges Deities to receive. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni knows all that springs from Gods, he knows the mystery of men. Giver of wealth is Agni, he uncloses both the doors to us when worshipped with our newest gift. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni inhabiteth with Gods and men who offer sacrifice. He cherisheth with great delight much wisdom, as all things that be, God among Gods adorable. May all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni who liveth in all streams, Lord of the Sevenfold Race of men, Him dweller in three homes we seek, best slayer of the Dasyus for Mandhātar, first in sacrifice. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni the Wise inhabiteth three gathering-places, triply formed. Decked as our envoy let the Sage bring hither and conciliate the Thrice Eleven Deities. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our Agni, thou art first among the Gods, and first mid living men. Thou only rulest over wealth. Round about thee, as natural dams, circumfluous the waters run. Let all the others die away. Next: HYMN XL. Indra-Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA and Agni, surely ye as Conquerors will give us wealth, Whereby in fight we may o’ercome that which is strong and firmly fixed, as Agni burns the woods with wind. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We set no snares to tangle you; Indra we worship and adore, Hero of heroes mightiest. Once may he come unto us with his Steed, come unto us to win us strength, and to complete the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, famous Indra-Agni, ye are dwellers in the midst of frays. Sages in wisdom, ye are knit to him who seeketh you as friends. Heroes, bestow on him his wish.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Nabhāka-like, with sacred song Indra's and Agni's praise I sing, Theirs to whom all this world belongs, this heaven and this mighty earth which bear rich treasure in their lap.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra and to Agni send your prayers, as was Nabhāka's wont,— Who oped with sideway opening the sea with its foundations seven—Indra all powerful in his might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tear thou asunder, as of old, like tangles of a creeping plant, Demolish thou the Dāsa's might. May we with Indra's help divide the treasure he hath gathered up.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time with this same song these men call Indra-Agni sundry ways, May we with our own heroes quell those who provoke us to the fight, and conquer those who strive with us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Two refulgent with their beams rise and come downward from the sky. By Indra's and by Agni's hest, flowing away, the rivers, run which they released from their restraint.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, many are thine aids, many thy ways of guiding us, Lord of the Bay Steeds, Hinva's Son. To a Good Hero come our prayers, which soon shall have accomplishment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Inspire him with your holy hymns, the Hero bright and glorious, Him who with might demolisheth even the brood of Śuṣṇa, and winneth for us the heavenly streams.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Inspire him worshipped with fair rites, the glorious Hero truly brave. He brake in pieces Śuṣṇa's brood who still expected not the stroke, and won for us the heavenly streams. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus have we sung anew to Indra-Agni, as sang our sires, Aṅgirases, and Mandhātar. Guard us with triple shelter and preserve us: may we be masters of a store of riches. Next: HYMN XLI. Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To make this Varuṇa come forth sing thou a song unto the band of Maruts wiser than thyself,— This Varuṇa who guardeth well the thoughts of men like herds of kine. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him altogether praise I with the song and hymns our fathers sang, and with Nabhāka's eulogies,— Him dwelling at the rivers’ source, surrounded by his Sisters Seven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The nights he hath encompassed, and stablished the morns with magic art visible over all is he. His dear Ones, following his Law, have prospered the Three Dawns for him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, visible o’er all the earth, stablished the quarters of the sky: He measured out the eastern place, that is the fold of Varuṇa: like a strong herdsman is the God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who supports the worlds of life, he who well knows the hidden names mysterious of the morning beams, He cherishes much wisdom, Sage, as heaven brings forth each varied form.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In whom all wisdom centres, as the nave is set within the wheel. Haste ye to honour Trita, as kine haste to gather in the fold, even as they muster steeds to yoke.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He wraps these regions as a robe; he contemplates the tribes of Gods and all the works of mortal men. Before the home of Varuṇa all the Gods follow his decree.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He is an Ocean far-removed, yet through the heaven to him ascends the worship which these realms possess. With his bright foot he overthrew their magic, and went up to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ruler, whose bright far-seeing rays, pervading all three earths, have filled the three superior realms of heaven. Firm is the seat of Varuṇa: over the Seven he rules as King.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who, after his decree, o’erspread the Dark Ones with a robe of light; Who measured out the ancient seat, who pillared both the worlds apart as the Unborn supported heaven. Let all the others die away. Next: HYMN XLII Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LORD of all wealth, the Asura propped the heavens, and measured out the broad earth's wide expanses. He, King supreme, approached all living creatures. All these are Varuṇa's holy operations.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So humbly worship Varuṇa the Mighty revere the wise Guard of World Immortal. May he vouchsafe us triply-barred protection. O Earth and Heaven, within your lap preserve us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sharpen this song of him who strives his utmost, sharpen, God Varuṇa, his strength and insight; May we ascend the ship that bears us safely, whereby we may pass over all misfortune.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, with songs the singer stones have made you hasten hitherward, Nāsatyas, to the Soma-draught. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As the sage Atri with his hymns, O Aśvins, called you eagerly, Nāsatyas, to the Soma-draught. Let all the others die away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So have I called you to our aid, even as the wise have called of old, Nāsatyas, to the Soma-draught. Let all the others die away. Next: HYMN XLIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THESE songs of mine go forth as lauds of Agni, the disposing Sage, Whose worshipper is ne’er o’erthrown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise Agni Jātavedas, I beget a song of praise for thee. Who willingly receivest it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy sharpened flames, O Agni, like the gleams of light that glitter through, Devour the forests with their teeth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gold-coloured, bannered with the smoke, urged by the wind, aloft to heaven Rise, lightly borne, the flames of fire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These lightly kindled fiery flames are all around made visible, Even as the gleanings of the Dawns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Jātavedas speeds along, the dust is black beneath his feet, When Agni spreads upon the earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Making the plants his nourishment, Agni devours and wearies not, Seeking the tender shrubs again.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bending him down with all his tongues, he flickers with his fiery glow Splendid is Agni in the woods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, thine home is in the floods: into the plants thou forcest way, And as their Child art born anew.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Worshipped with offerings shines thy flame, O Agni, from the sacred oil, With kisses on the ladle's mouth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us serve Agni with our hymns, Disposer, fed on ox and cow, Who bears the Soma on his back.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, thee, O Agni, do we seek with homage and with fuel, Priest Whose wisdom is most excellent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O worshipped with oblations, pure Agni, we call on thee as erst, Did Bhṛgu, Manus, Aṅgiras.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou, O Agni, by the fire, Sage by the Sage, Good by the Good, Friend by the Friend, art lighted up.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So wealth in thousands, food with store of heroes give thou to the sage, O Agni, to the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, Brother, made by strength, Lord of red steeds and brilliant sway, Take pleasure in this laud of mine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: My praises, Agni, go to thee, as the cows seek the stall to meet, The lowing calf that longs for milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, best Aṅgiras, to thee all people who have pleasant homes, Apart, have turned as to their wish.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The sages skilled in holy song and thinkers with their thoughts have urged Agni to share the sacred feast.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, Agni, unto thee the Priest, Invoker, strong in forays, pray Those who spin out the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In many a place, the same in look art thou, a Prince o’er all the tribes In battles we invoke thine aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pray thou to Agni, pray to him who blazes served with sacred oil: Let him give ear to this our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
