text: We call on thee as such, as one who hears, as Jātavedas, one, Agni! who beats away our foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I pray to Agni, King of men, the Wonderful, the President Of holy Laws: may he give ear.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him like a bridegroom, him who stirs all people, like a noble horse, Like a fleet steed, we instigate.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Slaying things deadly, burning up foes, Rākṣasas, on every side, Shine, Agni, with thy sharpened flame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou whom the people kindle even as Manus did, best Aṅgiras! O Agni, mark thou this my speech.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, made by strength! be thou born in the heavens or born in floods, As such we call on thee with songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, all the people, all the folk who have good dwellings, each apart, Send food for thee to eat thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, so may we, devout, gazed at by men, throughout our days, Pass lightly over all distress.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We venerate with cheerful hearts the cheerful Agni, dear to all, Burning, with purifying flame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So thou, O Agni rich in light, beaming like Sūrya with thy rays Boldly demolishest the gloom,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We pray to thee for this thy gift, Victor the gift that faileth not, O Agni, choicest wealth from thee. Next: HYMN XLIV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PAY service unto Agni with your fuel, rouse your Guest with oil: In him present your offerings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, do thou accept my laud, be magnified by this my song: Welcome my sweetly-spoken words.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, envoy, I place in front; the oblation-bearer I address: Here let him seat the Deities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the lofty flames of thee enkindled have gone up on high, Thy bright flames, thou Refulgent One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Beloved! let my ladles full of sacred oil come near to thee: Agni, accept our offerings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I worship Agni—may he hear!—the cheerful, the Invoker, Priest, Of varied splendour, rich in light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ancient Invoker, meet for praise, beloved Agni, wise and strong, The visitant of solemn rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, best Aṅgiras, accept straightway these offerings, and guide The seasonable sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Excellent God, with brilliant flames, enkindled bring thou hitherward, Knowing the way, the Heavenly Host.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, Sage and Herald, void of guile, ensign of sacrifices, him Smoke-bannered, rich in light, we seek.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, be our Guardian thou, God, against those who injure us: Destroy our foes, thou Son of Strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Making his body beautiful, Agni the Sage hath waxen by The singer and his ancient hymn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I invocate the Child of Strength, Agni with purifying flame, At this well-ordered sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So Agni, rich in many friends, with fiery splendour, seat thyself With Gods upon our sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mortal man who serves the God Agni within his own abode, For him he causes wealth to shine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni is head and height of heaven, the Master of the earth is he: He quickeneth the waters’ seed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Upward, O Agni, rise thy flames, pure and resplendent, blazing high, Thy lustres, fair effulgences.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Agni, thou as Lord of Light rulest o’er choicest gifts: may I, Thy singer, find defence in thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, they who understand stir thee to action with their thoughts: So let our songs enhance thy might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We ever claim the friendship of Agni, the singing messenger, Of God-like nature, void of guile.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni who bears most holy sway, the holy Singer, holy Sage, Shines holy when we worship him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, let my meditations, let my songs exalt thee evermore. Think, Agni, of our friendly bond,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If I were thou and thou wert I, O Agni, every prayer of thine Should have its due fulfilment here.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Excellent and Lord of wealth. art thou O Agni, rich in light: May we enjoy thy favouring grace.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, to thee whose laws stand fast our resonant songs of praise speed forth, As rivers hasten to the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, the Youthful Lord of men, who stirreth much and eateth all, The Sage, I glorify with hymns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Agni let us haste with lauds, the Guide of sacrificial rites, Armed with sharp teeth, the Mighty One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And let this man, good Agni, be with thee the singer of thy praise: Be gracious, Holy One, to him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou art sharer of our feast, wise, ever watchful as a Sage: Agni, thou shinest in the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, Sage, before our foes, before misfortunes fall on us, Excellent Lord, prolong our lives. Next: HYMN XLV. Indra

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HITHERWARD! they who light flame and straightway trim the sacred grass. Whose Friend is Indra ever young.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: High is their fuel, great their laud, wide is their splinter from the stake, Whose Friend is Indra ever young.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unequalled in fight the hero leads his army with the warrior chiefs. Whose Friend is Indra ever young.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The new-born Vṛtra-slayer asked his Mother, as he seized his shaft, Who are the fierce? Who are renowned?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Śavasī answered, He who seeks thine enmity will battle like A stately elephant on a hill.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And hear, O Maghavan; to him who craves of thee thou grantest all Whate’er thou makest firm is firm.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the Warrior Indra goes to battle, borne by noble steeds, Best of all charioteers is he.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Repel, O Thunder-armed, in all directions all attacks on us: And be our own most glorious God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra set our car in front, in foremost Place to win the spoil, He whom the wicked injure not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine enmity may we escape, and, Śakra, for thy bounty, rich In kine, may we come near to thee

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Softly approaching, Thunder-armed wealthy by hundreds, rich in steeds, Unrivalled, ready with our gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thine exalted excellence gives to thy worshippers each day Hundreds and thousands of thy boons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, we know thee breaker-down even of strong forts, winner of spoil, As one who conquers wealth for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Though thou art highest, Sage and Bold! let the drops cheer thee when we come To thee as to a trafficker.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring unto us the treasure of the opulent man who, loth to give, Hath slighted thee for gain of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, these friends of ours, supplied with Soma, wait and look to thee, As men with fodder to the herd.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And thee who art not deaf, whose cars are quick to listen, for our aid, We call to us from far away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thou hast listened, make our call one which thou never wilt forget, And be our very nearest Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When even now, when we have been in trouble, we have thought of thee, O Indra, give us gifts of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Lord of Strength, we rest on thee, as old men rest upon a staff: We long to have. thee dwell with us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra sing a song of praise, Hero of mighty valour, him Whom no one challenges to war.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hero, the Soma being shed, I pour the juice for thee to drink: Sate thee and finish thy carouse.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the fools, or those who mock beguile thee when they seek thine aid Love not the enemies of prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here let them with rich milky draught cheer thee to great munificence: Drink as the wild-bull drinks the lake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Proclaim in our assemblies what deeds, new and ancient, far away, The Vṛtra-slayer hath achieved.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In battle of a thousand arms Indra drank Kadrū's Soma juice: There he displayed his manly might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: True undeniable strength he found in Yadu and in Turvaśa, And conquered through the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him have I magnified, our Lord in, common, Guardian of your folk, Discloser of great wealth in kine;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ṛbhukṣan, not to be restrained, who strengthened Tugra's son in lauds, Indra beside the flowing juice;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who for Triśoka clave the hill that formed a wide receptacle, So that the cows might issue forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whate’er thy plan or purpose be, whate’er, in transport, thou wouldst do, Do it not, Indra, but be kind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: But little hath been heard of done upon the earth by one like thee i Let thine heart, Indra, turn to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine then shall be this high renown, thine shall these lofty praises be, When, Indra, thou art kind to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not for one trespass, not for two, O Hero, slay us, nor for three, Nor yet for many trespasses.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I fear one powerful like thee, the crusher-down of enemies, Mighty, repelling all attacks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O wealthy God, ne’er may I live to see my friend or son in need: Hitherward let thy heart be turned.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What friend, O people, unprovoked, hath ever said unto a friend, He turns and leaves us in distress?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hero, insatiate enjoy this Soma juice so near to thee, Even as a hunter rushing down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither I draw those Bays of thine yoked by our hymn, with splendid car, That thou mayst give unto the priests.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drive all our enemies away, smite down the foes who press around, And bring the wealth for which we long:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, that which is concealed in strong firm place precipitous: Bring us the wealth for which we long

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Great riches which the world of men shall recognize as sent by thee: Bring us the wealth for which we long. Next: HYMN XLVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE, Indra, Lord of ample wealth, our Guide, depend on one like thee, Thou driver of the Tawny Steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Hurler of the Bolt, we know thee true, the giver of our food, We know the giver of our wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O thou whose majesty the bards celebrate with their songs, thou Lord, Of hundred powers and hundred aids.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fair guidance hath the mortal man whom Aryaman, the Marut host, And Mitra, void of guile, protect.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kine, steeds, and hero strength he gains, and prospers, by the Ādityas sped, Ever in wealth which all desire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We pray to Indra for his gift, to him the Fearless and the Strong, We pray to him the Lord of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For verily combined in him are all the fearless powers of aid. Him, rich in wealth, let swift Steeds bring to us, his Bays, to Soma juice for his carouse:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, that most excellent carouse, Indra, which slays most enemies, With Heroes wins the light of heaven, and is invincible in war:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Which merits fame, all-bountiful! and, unsubdued, hath victory in deeds of might. So come to our libations, Strongest! Excellent! May we obtain a stall of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Responding to our wish for cows, for steeds, and chariots, as of old, Be gracious, Greatest of the Great

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Hero, nowhere can I find the bounds of thy munificence. Still do thou favour us, O Bolt-armed Maghavan: with strength hast thou rewarded hymns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: High, glorifier of his friend, he knows all generations, he whom many praise. All races of mankind with ladies lifted up invoke that Mighty Indra's aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be he our Champion and Protector in great deeds, rich in all wealth, the Vṛtra-slayer, Maghavan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In the wild raptures of the juice sing to your Hero with high laud, to him the Wise, To Indra, glorious in his name, the Mighty One, even as the hymn alloweth it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou givest wealth to me myself, thou givest treasure, Excellent! and the strong steed, O Much-invoked, in deeds of might, yea, even now.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, Sovran Ruler of all precious things, who even hath power o’er this fair form of his, As now it taketh shape, and afterward,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We praise, so that the Mighty One may speed to you, Pourer of bounties , Traveller, prepared to go. Thou favourest the Maruts known to all, by song and sacrifice. With song and praise I sing to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We in the sacrifice perform their will whose voice is lifted high, The worship of those Thundering Ones who o’er the ridges of these mountains fly in troops.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Mightiest, bring us that which crushes men of evil minds, Wealth suited to our needs, O Stirrer of the thought, best wealth, O thou who stirrest thought.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Winner, noble winner, strong, wondrous, most splendid, excellent, Sole Lord of victory, bring all-overpowering wealth, joy-giving, chief in deeds of might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now let the godless man approach who hath received reward so great As Vaśa, Aśvya, when this light of morning dawned, received from Pṛthuśravas, from Kanīta's son.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Steeds sixty thousand and ten thousand kine, and twenty hundred camels I obtained; Ten hundred brown in hue, and other ten red in three spots: in all, ten thousand kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ten browns that make my wealth increase, fleet steeds whose tails are long and fair, Turn with swift whirl my chariot wheel;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The gifts which Pṛthuśravas gave, Kanīta's son munificent. He gave a chariot wrought of gold: the prince was passing bountiful, and won himself most lofty fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come thou to this great rite of ours, Vāyu! to give us vigorous light. We have served thee that thou mightest give much to us, yea, mightest quickly give great wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who with thrice seven times seventy horses comes to us, invested with the rays of morn, Through these our Soma-draughts and those who press, to give, drinker of pure bright Soma Juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who hath inclined this glorious one, bounteous himself, to give me gifts. Borne on firm chariot with the prosperous Nahuṣa, wise, to a man yet more devout.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sole Lord in beauty meet for praise, O Vāyu, dropping fatness down, Hurried along by steeds, by camels, and by hounds, spreads forth thy train: even this it is.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, as a prize dear to the strong, the sixty thousand have I gained, Bulls that resemble vigorous steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To me come oxen like a herd, yea, unto me the oxen come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And in the grazing herd he made a hundred camels bleat for me, And twenty hundred mid the white.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hundred has the sage received, Dāsa Balbūtha's and Tarukṣa's gifts. These are thy people, Vāyu, who rejoice with Indra for their guard, rejoice with Gods for guards.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And now to Vaśa Aśvya here this stately woman is led forth, Adorned with ornaments of gold. Next: HYMN XLVII. Ādityas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GREAT help ye give the worshipper, Varuṇa, Mitra, Mighty Ones! No sorrow ever reaches him whom ye, Ādityas, keep from harm. Yours are incomparable aids, and good the succour they afford.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Gods, Ādityas, well ye know the way to keep all woes afar. As the birds spread their sheltering wings, spread your protection over us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As the birds spread their sheltering wings let your protection cover us. We mean all shelter and defence, ye who have all things for your own.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To whomsoever they, Most Wise, have given a home and means of life, O'er the whole riches of this man they, the Ādityas, have control.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As drivers of the car avoid ill roads, let sorrows pass us by. May we be under Indra's guard, in the Ādityas’ favouring grace.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For verily men sink and faint through loss of wealth which ye have given. Much hath he gained from you, O Gods, whom ye, Ādityas, have approached.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On him shall no fierce anger fall, no sore distress shall visit him, To whom, Ādityas, ye have lent your shelter that extendeth far.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Resting in you, O Gods, we are like men who fight in coats of mail. Ye guard us from each great offence, ye guard us from each lighter fault.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Aditi defend us, may Aditi guard and shelter us, Mother of wealthy Mitra and of Aryaman and Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The shelter, Gods, that is secure, auspicious, free from malady, A sure protection, triply strong, even that do ye extend to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Look down on us, Ādityas, as a guide exploring from the bank. Lead us to pleasant ways as men lead horses to an easy ford.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ill be it for the demons' friend to find us or come near to us. But for the milch-cow be it well, and for the man who strives for fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Each evil deed made manifest, and that which is concealed, O Gods, The whole thereof remove from us to Trita Āptya far away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Daughter of Heaven, the dream that bodes evil to us or to our kine, Remove, O Lady of the Light, to Trita Āptya far away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even if, O Child of Heaven, it make a garland or a chain of gold, The whole bad dream, whate’er it be, to Trita Āptya we consign.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him whose food and work is this, who comes to take his share therein, To Trita, and to Dvita, Dawn! bear thou the evil dream away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As we collect the utmost debt, even the eighth and sixteenth part, So unto Āptya we transfer together all the evil dream.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now have we conquered and obtained, and from our trespasses are free. Shine thou away the evil dream, O Dawn, whereof we are afraid. Yours are incomparable aids, and good the succour they afford. Next: HYMN XLVIII. Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WISELY have I enjoyed the savoury viand, religious-thoughted, best to find out treasure, The food to which all Deities and mortals, calling it meath, gather themselves together.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tlou shalt be Aditi as thou hast entered within, appeaser of celestial anger. Indu, enjoying Indra's friendship, bring us—as a swift steed the car—forward to riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We have drunk Soma and become immortal; we have attained the light, the Gods discovered. Now what may foeman's malice do to harm us? What, O Immortal, mortal man's deception?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Absorbed into the heart, be sweet, O Indu, as a kind father to his son, O Soma, As a wise Friend to friend: do thou, wide-ruler, O Soma, lengthen out our days for living.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These glorious drops that give me freedom have I drunk. Closely they knit my joints as straps secure a car. Let them protect my foot from slipping on the way: yea, let the drops I drink preserve me from disease.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make me shine bright like fire produced by friction: give us a clearer sight and make us better. For in carouse I think of thee, O Soma, Shall I, as a rich man, attain to comfort?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we enjoy with an enlivened spirit the juice thou givest, like ancestral riches. O Soma, King, prolong thou our existence as Sūrya makes the shining days grow longer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: King Soma, favour us and make us prosper: we are thy devotees; of this be mindful. Spirit and power are fresh in us, O Indu give us not up unto our foeman's pleasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou hast settled in each joint, O Soma, aim of men's eyes and guardian of our bodies. When we offend against thine holy statutes, as a kind Friend, God, best of all, be gracious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May I be with the Friend whose heart is tender, who, Lord of Bays! when quaffed will never harm me- This Soma now deposited within me. For this, I pray for longer life to Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our maladies have lost their strength and vanished: they feared, and passed away into the darkness. Soma hath risen in us, exceeding mighty, and we are come where men prolong existence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: , Fathers, that Indu which our hearts have drunken, Immortal in himself, hath entered mortals. So let us serve this Soma with oblation, and rest securely in his grace and favour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Associate with the Fathers thou, O Soma, hast spread thyself abroad through earth and heaven. So with oblation let us serve thee, Indu, and so let us become the lords of riches,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us your blessing, O ye Gods’ preservers. Never may sleep or idle talk control us. But evermore may we, as friends of Soma, speak to the synod with brave sons around us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On all sides,. Soma, thou art our life-giver: aim of all eyes, light-finder, come within us. Indu, of one accord with thy protections both from behind and from before preserve us. Next: HYMN XLIX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI, come hither with thy fires; we choose thee as Invoking Priest. Let the extended ladle full of oil balm thee, best Priest, to sit on sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For unto thee, O Aṅgiras, O Son of Strength, move ladles in the sacrifice. To Agni, Child of Force, whose locks drop oil, we seek, foremost in sacrificial rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, thou art Disposer, Sage, Herald, bright God! and worshipful, Best offerer, cheerful, to be praised in holy rites, pure Lord! by singers with their hymns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most Youthful and Eternal, bring the longing Gods to me, the guileless, for the feast. Come, Vasu, to the banquet that is well-prepared: rejoice thee, gracious, with our songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Famed art thou, Agni, far and wide, Preserver, righteous, and a Sage. The holy singers, O refulgent kindled God! arrangers, call on thee to come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shine, Most Resplendent! blaze, send bliss unto the folk, and to thy worshipper Great art thou. So may my princes, with good fires, subduing foes, rest in the keeping of the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, as thou burnest down to earth even high-grown underwood, So, bright as Mitra is, burn him who injures us, him who plots ill against thy friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us not as a prey to mortal enemy, nor to the wicked friend of fiends. With conquering guards, auspicious, unassailable, protect us, O Most Youthful God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Protect us, Agni, through the first, protect us through the second hymn, Protect us through three hymns, O Lord of Power and Might, through four hymns, Vasu, guard thou us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Preserve us from each fiend who brings the Gods no gift, preserve thou us in deeds of strength: For we possess in thee the nearest Friend of all, for service of the Gods and weal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Holy Agni, give us wealth renowned with men and strengthening life. Bestow on us, O Helper, that which many crave, more glorious still by righteousness;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wherewith we may o’ercome our rivals in the war, o’erpowering the foe's designs. So wax thou by our food, O Excellent in strength. Quicken our thoughts that find out wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni is even as a bull who whets and brandishes his horns. Well-sharpened are his jaws which may not be withstood: the Child of Strength hath powerful teeth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Not to be stayed, O Bull, O Agni, are thy teeth when thou art spreading far and wide. Make our oblations duly offered up, O Priest, and give us store of precious things.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou liest in the wood: from both thy Mothers mortals kindle thee. Unweariedly thou bearest up the offerer's gifts, then shinest bright among the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And so the seven priests, O Agni, worship thee, Free-giver, Everlasting One. Thou cleavest through the rock with heat and fervent glow. Agni, rise up above the men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For you let us whose grass is trimmed call Agni, Agni, restless God. Let us whose food is offered call to all the tribes Agni the Invoking Priest of men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, with noble psalm that tells his wish he dwells, thinking on thee who guardest him. Speedily bring us strength of many varied sorts to be most near to succour us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, Praise-singer! Lord of men, God burner-up of Rākṣasas, Mighty art thou, the ever-present Household-Lord, Home-friend and Guardian from the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let no fiend come among us, O thou rich in light, no spell of those who deal in spells. To distant pastures drive faint hunger: far away, O Agni, chase the demons’ friends. Next: HYMN L. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BOTH boons,—may Indra, hitherward turned, listen to this prayer of ours, And mightiest Maghavan with thought inclined to us come near to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For him, strong, independent Ruler, Heaven and Earth have fashioned forth for power and might. Thou seatest thee as first among thy peers in place, for thy soul longs for Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fill thyself full, O Lord of wealth, O Indra, with the juice we shed. We know thee, Lord of Bay Steeds victor in the fight, vanquishing e’en the invincible.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Changeless in truth, O Maghavan Indra, let it be as thou in wisdom willest it. May we, O fair of check, win booty with thine aid, O Thunderer, swiftly seeking it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, with all thy saving helps give us assistance, Lord of power. For after thee we follow even as glorious bliss, thee, Hero, finder-out of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Increaser of our steeds and multiplying kine, a golden well, O God, art thou, For no one may impair the gifts laid up in thee. Bring me whatever thing I ask.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou,—come to the worshipper!—wilt find great wealth to make us rich. Fill thyself full, O Maghavan, for gain of kine, full, Indra, for the gain of steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou as thy gift bestowest many hundred herds, yea, many thousands dost thou give. With singers' hymns have we brought the Fort-render near, singing to Indra for his grace.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether the simple or the sage, Indra, have offered praise to thee, He Śatakratu! by his love hath gladdened thee, ambitious! ever pressing on!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If he the Strong of arm, the breaker-down of forts, the great Destroyer, hear my call, We, seeking riches cry to Indra, Lord of wealth, to Śatakratu with our lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We count not then as sinners, nor as niggardly or foolish men, When with the Soma juice which we have shed we make Indra, the Mighty One, our Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him have we yoked in fight, the powerful Conqueror, debt-claimer, not to be deceived. Best charioteer, the Victor marks each fault, he knows the strong to whom he will come near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, give us security from that whereof we are afraid. Help us, O Maghavan, let thy succour give us this: drive away foes and enemies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou, O liberal Lord of bounty, strengthenest his ample home who worships thee. So Indra, Maghavan, thou Lover of the Song, we with pressed Soma call on thee,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra is Vṛtra-slayer, guard, our best defender from the foe. May he preserve our last and middlemost, and keep watch from behind us and before.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Defend us from behind, below, above, in front, on all sides, Indra, shield us well. Keep far away from us the terror sent from heaven: keep impious weapons far away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Protect us, Indra, each to-day, each morrow, and each following day. Our singers, through all days, shalt thou, Lord of the brave, keep safely both by day and night.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A crushing Warrior, passing rich is Maghavan, endowed with all heroic might. Thine arms, O Śatakratu, are exceeding strong, arms which have grasped the thunderbolt. Next: HYMN LI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: OFFER ye up as praise to him that wherein Indra takes delight. The Soma-bringers magnify Indra's great energy with hymns. Good are the gifts that Indra gives.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sole among chiefs, companionless, impetuous, and peerless, he Hath waxen great o’er many folk, yea., over all things born, in might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of swift bounty, he will win e’en with a steed of worthless sort. This, Indra, must be told of thee who wilt perform heroic deeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us hither: let us pay devotions that enhance thy might, For which, Most Potent! thou wouldst fain bless the man here who strives for fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou, O Indra, makest yet more bold the spirit of the bold Who with strong Soma serveth thee, still ready with his reverent prayers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Worthy of song, he looketh down as a man looketh into wells. Pleased with the Soma-bringer's skill he maketh him his mate and friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In strength and wisdom all the Gods, Indra, have yielded unto thee. Be thou the Guard of all, O thou whom many praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praised, Indra, is this might of thine, best for the service of the Gods, That thou with power dost slay Vṛtra, O Lord of Strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He makes the races of mankind like synods of the Beauteous One. Indra knows this his manifest deed, and is renowned.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy might, O Indra, at its birth, thee also, and thy mental power, In thy care, Maghavan rich in kine! they have increased exceedingly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vṛtra-slayer, thou and I will both combine for winning spoil. Even malignity will consent, O Bolt-armed Hero, unto us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us extol this Indra as truthful and never as untrue. Dire is his death who pours no gifts great light hath he who offers them. Good are the gifts that Indra gives. Next: HYMN LII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH powers of Mighty Ones hath he, Ancient, Beloved, been equipped, Through whom the Father Manu made prayers efficacious with the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, Maker of the sky, let stones wet with the Soma ne’er forsake, Nor hymns and prayer that must be said.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra who knew full well disclosed the kine to the Aṅgirases. This his great deed must be extolled.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, promoter of the song, the sage's Strengthener as of old, Shall come to bless and succour us at presentation of this laud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now after their desire's intent the pious singers with the cry Of Hail! have sung loud hymns to thee, Indra, to gain a stall of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With Indra rest all deeds of might, deeds done and yet to be performed, Whom singers know devoid of guile.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the Five Tribes with all their men to Indra have sent out their voice, And when the priest hath strewn much grass, this is the Friend's own dwelling-place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This praise is verily thine own: thou hast performed these manly deeds, And sped the wheel upon its way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At the o’erflowing of this Steer, boldly he strode for life, and took Soma as cattle take their corn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Receiving this and craving help, we, who with you are Dakṣa's sons, Would fain exalt the Maruts’ Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, Hero, with the singers we sing to the duly-coming Band. Allied with thee may we prevail.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With us are raining Rudras, clouds accordant in call to battle, at the death of Vṛtra, The strong assigned to him who sings and praises. May Gods with Indra at their head protect us. Next: HYMN LIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY our hymns give thee great delight. Display thy bounty, Thunderer. Drive off the enemies of prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Crush with thy foot the niggard churls who bring no gifts. Mighty art thou There is not one to equal thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art the Lord of Soma pressed, Soma impressed is also thine. Thou art the Sovran of the folk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, go thou forth, dwelling in heaven and listening to the prayers of men: Thou fillest both the heavens and earth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even that hill with rocky heights, with hundreds, thousands, held within. Thou for thy worshippers brakest through.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call on thee both night and day to taste the flowing Soma juice: Do thou fulfil our heart's desire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where is that ever-youthful Steer, strong. necked and never yet bent down? What Brahman ministers to him?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To whose libation doth the Steer, betake him with delight therein? Who takes delight in Indra now?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom, Vṛtra-slayer, have thy gift and hero powers accompanied? Who is thy dearest in the laud?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thee among mankind, among the Pūrus is this Soma shed. Hasten thou hither: drink thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This, growing by Soma and by Śaryaṇāvān, dear to thee, In Ārjīkīya, cheers thee best.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hasten thou hitherward, and drink this for munificence to-day, Delightful for thine eager draught. Next: HYMN LIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOUGH, Indra, thou art called by men from east and west, from north and south, Come hither quickly with fleet steeds

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If in the effluence of heaven, rich in its light, thou takest joy, Or in the sea in Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With songs I call thee, Great and Wide, even as a cow to profit us, Indra, to drink the Soma-draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither, O Indra, let thy Bays bear up and, bring upon thy car Thy glory, God! and majesty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Indra, wouldst be sung and praised as great, strong, lordly in thy deeds Come hither, drink our Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We who have shed the Soma and prepared the feast are calling thee. To sit on this our sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As, Indra, thou art evermore the common Lord of all alike, As such we invocate thee now.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men with stones have milked for thee this nectar of the Soma juice: Indra, be pleased with it, and drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Neglect all pious men with skill in sacred song: come hitherward, With speed, and give us high renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gods, may the mighty rest unharmed, the King who gives me spotted kine, Kine decked with golden ornaments.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Beside a thousand spotted kine I have received a gift of gold, Pure, brilliant, and exceeding great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Durgaha's grandsons, giving me a thousand kine, munificent, Have won renown among the Gods. Next: HYMN LV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LOUD singing at the sacred rite where Soma flows we priests invoke With haste, that he may help, as the bard's Cherisher, Indra who findeth wealth for you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom with fair helm, in rapture of the juice, the firm resistless slayers hinder not: Giver of glorious wealth to him who sing a his praise, honouring him who toils and pours:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Śakra, who like a curry-comb for horses or a golden goad, Indra, the Vṛtra-slayer, urges eagerly the opening of the stall of kine:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who for the worshipper scatters forth ample wealth, even though buried, piled in heaps: May Indra, Lord of Bay Steeds, fair-helmed Thunderer, act at his pleasure, as he lists.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hero whom many praise, what thou hast longed for, oven of old, from men. All that we offer unto thee, O Indra, now, sacrifice, laud, effectual speech.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Soma, Much-invoked, Bolt-armed! for thy carouse, Celestial, Soma-drinker come. Thou to the man who- prays and pours the juice hast been best giver of delightful wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here, verily, yesterday we let the Thunder-wielder drink his fill. So in like manner offer him the juice today. Now range you by the Glorious One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even the wolf, the savage beast that rends the sheep, follows the path of his decrees. So graciously accepting, Indra, this our praise, with wondrous thought come forth to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What manly deed of vigour now remains that Indra hath not done? Who hath not heard his glorious title and his fame, the Vṛtra-slayer from his birth?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: 'How great his power resistless! how invincible the Vṛtra-slayer's matchless might! Indra excels all usurers who see the day, excels all traffickers in strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Vṛtra-slayer, we, thy very constant worshippers, Bring prayers ne’er heard before to thee, O Much-invoked, O Thunder-armed, to be thy meed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O thou of mighty acts, the aids that are in thee call forward many an eager hope. Past the drink-offerings, Vasu, even of the good, hear my call, Strongest God, and come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Verily, Indra, we are thine, we worshippers depend on thee. For there is none but only thou to show us race, O Maghavan, thou much invoked.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From this our misery and famine set us free, from this dire curse deliver us. Succour us with thine help and with thy wondrous thought. Most Mighty, finder of the way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now let your Soma juice be poured; be not afraid, O Kali's sons. This darkening sorrow goes away; yea, of itself it vanishes. Next: HYMN LVI. Ādityas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now pray we to these Ksatriyas, to the Ādityas for their aid, These who are gracious to assist.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Mitra bear us o’er distress, and Varuṇa and Aryaman, Yea, the Ādityas, as they know.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For wonderful and meet for praise is these Ādityas’ saving help To him who offers and prepares.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mighty aid of you, the Great, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, We claim to be our sure defence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guard us, Ādityas, still alive, before the deadly weapon strike: Are yc not they who hear our call?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What sheltering defence ye have for him who toils in pouring gifts, Graciously bless ye us therewith.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ādityas, Gods, from sorrow there is freedom; for the sinless, wealth, O ye in whom no fault is seen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not this fetter bind us fast: may he release us for success; For strong is Indra and renowned.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Gods who fain would lend your aid, destroy not us as ye destroy Your enemies who go astray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And thee too, O Great Aditi, thee also, Goddess, I address, Thee very gracious to assist.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Save us in depth and shallow from the foe, thou Mother of Strong Sons Let no one of our seed be harmed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far-spread! wide-ruling! grant that we, unharmed by envy, may expand Grant that our progeny may live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those who, the Princes of the folk, in native glory, ne’er deceived, Maintain their statutes, void of guile—

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, from mouth of ravening wolves, O ye Ādityas, rescue us, Like a bound thief, O Aditi.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ādityas, let this arrow, yea, let this malignity depart From us or e’er it strike us dead.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Bountiful Ādityas, we have evermore enjoyed your help, Both now and in die days of old.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To every one, O ye Most Wise, who turneth even from sin to you, Ye Gods vouchsafe that he may live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May this new mercy profit us, which, ye Ādityas, frees like one, Bound from his bonds, O Aditi.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O ye Ādityas, this your might is not to be despised by us: So be ye graciously inclined.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not Vivasvān's weapon nor the shaft, Ādityas, wrought with skill, Destroy us ere old age be nigh.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On every side dispel all sin, Ādityas, all hostility, Indigence, and combined attack. Next: HYMN LVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: EVEN as a car to give us aid, we draw thee hither for our bliss, Strong in thy deeds, checking assault, Lord, Mightiest Indra, of the brave!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Great in thy power and wisdom, Strong, with thought that comprehendeth all Thou hast filled full with majesty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou very Mighty One, whose hands by virtue of thy greatness grasp, The golden bolt that breaks its way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your Lord of might that ne’er hath bent, that ruleth over all mankind, I call, that he, as he is wont, may aid the chariots and the men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom, ever furthering, in frays that win the light, in both the hosts Men call to succour and to help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, the Strong, the measureless, worthy of praise, Most Bountiful, Sole Ruler even over wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, for his ample bounty, him, this Indra do I urge to drink, Who, as his praise was sung of old, the Dancer, is the Lord of men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou Mighty One, whose friendship none of mortals ever hath obtained None will attain unto thy might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aided by thee, with thee allied, in frays for water and for sun, Bolt-armed! may we win ample spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So seek we thee with sacrifice and songs, chief Lover of the Song, As, in our battles Indra, thou to Purumayya gavest help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Thunderer, thou whose friendship and whose onward guidance both are sweet, Thy sacrifice must be prepared.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To us, ourselves, give ample room, give for our dwelling ample room Give ample room to us to live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We count the banquet of the Gods a spacious pathway for the men, And for the cattle, and the car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Six men, yea, two and two, made glad with Soma juice, come near to me With offerings pleasant to the taste.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Two brown-hued steeds, Indrota's gift, two bays from Rksa's son were mine, From Asvamedha's son two red.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From Atithigva good car-steeds; from Arksa rein-obeying steeds, From Asvamedha beauteous ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indrota, Atithigva's son, gave me six horses matched with mares And Patakratu gave besides.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Marked above all, amid the brown, is the red mare Vṛṣanvati, Obedient to the rein and whip.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O bound to me by deeds of might, not even the man who loves to blame. Hath found a single fault in you. Next: HYMN LVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I SEND you forth the song of praise for Indu, hero-gladdener. With hymn and plenty he invites you to complete the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou wishest for thy kine a bull, for those who long for his approach, For those who turn away from him, lord of thy cows whom none may kill.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The dappled kine who stream with milk prepare his draught of Soma juice: Clans in the birth-place of the Gods, in the three luminous realms of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise, even as he is known, with song Indra the guardian of the kine, The Son of Truth, Lord of the brave.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither his Bay Steeds have been sent, red Steeds are on the sacred grass,, Where we in concert sing our songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra Thunder-armed the kine have yielded mingled milk and meath, What time he found them in the vault.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When I and Indra mount on high up to the Bright One's place and home, We, having drunk of meath, will reach his seat whose Friends are three times seven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing, sing ye forth your songs of praise, ye Briyamedhas, sing your songs: Yea, let young children sing their lauds as a strong castle praise ye him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now loudly let the viol sound, the lute send out its voice with might, Shrill be, the music of the string. To Indra. is the hymn up-raised.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When hither speed the dappled cows, unflinching, easy to be milked, Seize quickly, as it bursts away, the Soma juice for Indra's drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra hath drunk, Agni hath drunk. all Deities have drunk their fill. Here Varuṇa shall have his home, to whom the floods have sung aloud as mother-kine unto their calves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Varuṇa, to whom belong Seven Rivers, art a glorious God. The waters flow into thy throat as ’twere a pipe with ample mouth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who hath made the fleet steeds spring, well-harnessed, to the worshipper, He, the swift Guide, is that fair form that loosed the horses near at hand.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, the very Mighty, holds his enemies in utter scorn. He, far away, and yet a child, cleft the cloud smitten by his voice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, yet a boy exceeding small, mounted his newly-fashioned car. He for his Mother and his Sire cooked the wild mighty buffalo.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of the home, fair-helmeted, ascend thy chariot wrought of gold. We will attend the Heavenly One, the thousand-footed, red of hue, matchless, who blesses where he goes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With reverence they come hitherward to him as to. a Sovran lord, That they may bring him near for this man's good success, to prosper and bestow his gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Priyamedhas have observed the offering of the men of old, Of ancient custom, while they strewed the sacred grass, and spread their sacrificial food. Next: HYMN LIX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HE who, as Sovran Lord of men, moves with his chariots unrestrained, The Vṛtra-slayer vanquisher, of fighting hosts, preeminent, is praised with song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Honour that Indra, Puruhanman! for his aid, in whose sustaining hand of old, The splendid bolt of thunder was deposited, as the great Sun was set in heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No one by deed attains to him who works and strengthens evermore: No, not by sacrifice, to Indra. praised o all, resistless, daring, bold in might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The potent Conqueror, invincible in war, him at whose birth the Mighty Ones, The Kine who spread afar , sent their loud voices out, heavens, earths seat their loud voices out,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, if a hundred heavens and if a hundred earths were thine— No, not a thousand Suns could match thee at thy birth, not both the worlds, O Thunderer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Hero, hast performed thy hero deeds with might, yea, all with strength, O Strongest One. Maghavan, help us to a stable full of kine, O Thunderer, with wondrous aids.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not a godless mortal gain this food, O thou whose life is long! But one who yokes the bright-hued steeds, the Etasas, even Indra yoker of the Bays.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Urge ye the Conqueror to give, your Indra greatly to be praised, To be invoked in shallow waters and in depths, to be invoked in deeds of might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vasu, O thou Hero, raise us up to ample opulence. Raise us to gain of mighty wealth, O Maghavan, O Indra, to sublime renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, thou justifiest us, and tramplest down thy slanderers. Guard thyself, valiant Hero, in thy vital parts: strike down the Dāsa with thy blows.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man who brings no sacrifice, inhuman, godless, infidel, Him let his friend the mountain cast to rapid death, the mountain cast the Dasyu down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Mightiest Indra, loving us, gather thou up, as grains of corn, Within thine hand, of these their kine, to give away, yea, gather twice as loving us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O my companions, wish for power. How may we perfect Sara's praise, The liberal princely patron, never to be harmed?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By many a sage whose grass is trimmed thou art continually praised, That thou, O Sara, hast bestowed here one and here another calf.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The noble, Suradeva's son, hath brought a calf, led by the car to three of us. As a chief brings a goat to milk. Next: HYMN LX. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O AGNI, with thy mighty wealth guard us from all malignity, Yea, from all hate of mortal man.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For over thee, O Friend from birth, the wrath of man hath no control: Nay, Guardian of the earth art thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, with all the Gods, O Son of Strength, auspicious in thy flame. Give us wealth bringing all things good.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Malignities stay not from wealth the mortal man whom, Agni, thou Protectest while he offers gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sage Agni, be whom thou dost urge, in worship of the Gods, to wealth, With thine assistance winneth kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Riches with many heroes thou hast for the man who offers gifts: Lead thou us on to higher bliss.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Save us, O Jātavedas, nor abandon us to him who sins, Unto the evil-hearted man.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, let no godless man avert thy bounty as a God: Over all treasures thou art Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, Son of Strength, thou aidest us to what is great and excellent. Those, Vasu! Friend! who sing thy praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let our songs come anear to him beauteous and bright with piercing flame Our offerings, with our homage, to the Lord of wealth, to him whom many praise, for help:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Agni Jātavedas, to the Son of Strength, that he may give us precious gifts, Immortal, from of old Priest among mortal men, the most delightful in the house.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, made yours by sacrifice, Agni, while holy rites advance; Agni, the first in songs, first with the warrior steed; Agni to win the land for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Agni who is Lord of wealth vouchsafe us food for friendship sake. Agni we ever seek for seed and progeny, the Vasu who protects our lives.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Solicit with your chants, for help, Agni the God with piercing flame, For riches famous Agni, Purumīlha and ye men! Agni to light our dwelling well.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni we laud that he may keep our foes afar, Agni to give us health and strength. Let him as Guardian be invoked in all the tribes, the lighter-up of glowing brands. Next: HYMN LXI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PREPARE oblation: let him come; and let the minister serve again Who knows the ordering thereof,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rejoicing in his friendship, let the priest be seated over man, Beside the shoot of active power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, glowing bright beyond all thought, they seek among the race of man; With him for tongue they seize the food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He hath inflamed the twofold plain: life-giving, he hath climbed the wood, And with his tongue hath struck the rock.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wandering here the radiant Calf finds none to fetter him, and seeks The Mother to declare his praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And now that great and mighty team, the team of horses that are his, And traces of his car, are seen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The seven milk a single cow; the two set other five to work, On the stream's loud-resounding bank.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Entreated by Vivasvān's ten, Indra cast down the water-jar With threefold hammer from the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three times the newly-kindled flame proceeds around the sacrifice: The priests anoint it with the meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With reverence they drain the fount that circles with its wheel above, Exhaustless, with the mouth below.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The pressing-stones are set at work: the meath is poured into the tank, At the out-shedding of the fount.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye cows, protect the fount: the two Mighty Ones bless the sacrifice. The handles twain are wrought of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour on the juice the ornament which reaches both the heaven and earth Supply the liquid to the Bull.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These know their own abiding-place: like calves beside the mother cows They meet together with their kin.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Devouring in their greedy jaws, they make sustaining food in heaven, To Indra, Agni light and prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Pious One milked out rich food, sustenance dealt in portions seven, Together with the Sun's seven rays.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I took some Soma when the Sun rose up, O Mitra, Varuṇa. That is the sick man's medicine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From where oblations must be laid, which is the Well-beloved's home, He with his tongue hath compassed heaven. Next: HYMN LXII. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ROUSE ye for him who keeps the Law, yoke your steeds, Aśvins, to your car Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Aśvins, with your car more swift than is the twinkling of an eye Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, ye overlaid with cold the fiery pit for Atri's sake: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Where are ye? whither are ye gone? whither, like falcons, have ye flown? Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If ye at any time this day are listening to this my call, Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Aśvins, first to hear our prayer, for closest kinship I approach: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Atri ye, O Aśvins, made a dwelling-place to shield him well, Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye warded off the fervent heat for Atri when he sweetly spake: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Erst Saptavadhri by his prayer obtained the trenchant edge of fire: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, O ye Lords of wealth, and listen to this call of mine: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What is this praise told forth of you as Elders in the ancient way? Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One common brotherhood is yours, Aśvins your kindred is the same: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is your chariot, Aśvins, which speeds through the regions, earth and heaven Let your protecting aid be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Approach ye hitherward to us with thousands both of steeds and kine: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pass us not by, remember us with thousands both of kine and steeds: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The purple-tinted Dawn hath risen, and true to Law hath made the light Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He looked upon the Aśvins, as an axe-armed man upon a tree: Let your protecting help be near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By the black band encompassed round, break it down, bold one, like a fort. Let your protecting help be near. Next: HYMN LXIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: EXERTING all our strength with thoughts of power we glorify in speech Agni your dear familiar Friend, the darling Guest in every home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom, served with sacrificial oil like Mitra, men presenting gifts Eulogize with their songs of praise

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Much-lauded Jātavedas, him who bears oblations up to heaven Prepared in service of the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To noblest Agni, Friend of man, best Vṛtra-slayer, are we come, Him in whose presence Rksa's son, mighty Srutarvan, waxes great;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To deathless Jātavedas, meet for praise, adored, with sacred oil, Visible through the gloom of night

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even Agni whom these priestly men worship with sacrificial gifts, With lifted ladles offering them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, this our newest hymn hath been addressed from us to thee, O cheerful Guest, well-born, most wise, worker of wonders, ne’er deceived.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, may it be dear to thee, most grateful, and exceeding sweet: Grow mightier, eulogized therewith.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Splendid with splendours may it be, and in the battle with the foe Add loftier glory to thy fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Steed, cow, a lord of heroes, bright like Indra, who shall fill the car. Whose high renown ye celebrate, and people praise each glorious deed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou whom Gopavana made glad with song, O Agni Aṅgiras, Hear this my call, thou Holy One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou whom the priestly folk implore to aid the gathering of the spoil, Such be thou in the fight with foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I, called to him who reels with joy, Srutarvan, Rksa's son, shall stroke The heads of four presented steeds, like the long wool of fleecy rams.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Four coursers with a splendid car, Savistha's horses, fleet of foot, Shall bring me to the sacred feast, as flying steeds brought Tugra's son.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The very truth do I declare to thee, Paruṣṇī, mighty flood. Waters! no man is there who gives more horses than Savistha gives. Next: HYMN LXIV. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YOKE, Agni, as a charioteer, thy steeds who best invite the Gods: As ancient Herald seat thyself.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, God, as skilfullest of all, call for us hitherward the Gods: Give all our wishes sure effect.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou, Most Youthful, Son of Strength, thou to whom sacrifice is paid, Art holy, faithful to the Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Agni, Lord of wealth and spoil hundredfold, thousandfold, is head And chief of riches and a Sage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As craftsmen bend the felly, so bend at our general call: come nigh, Aṅgiras, to the sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, O Virūpa, rouse for him, Strong God who shines at early morn, Fair praise with voice that ceases not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With missile of this Agni, his who looks afar, will we lay low The thief in combat for the kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the Companies of Gods fail us, like Dawns that float away, Like cows who leave the niggardly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the sinful tyranny of any fiercely hating foe Smite us, as billows smite a ship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, God, the people sing reverent praise to thee for strength: With terrors trouble thou the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wilt thou not, Agni, lend us aid in winning cattle, winning wealth? Maker of room, make room for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In this great battle cast us not aside as one who bears a load: Snatch up the wealth and win it all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, let this plague pursue and fright another and not us: Make our impetuous strength more strong.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The reverent or unwearied man whose holy labour he accepts, Him Agni favours with success.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Abandoning the foeman's host pass hither to this company: Assist the men with whom I stand.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As we have known thy gracious help, as of a Father, long ago, So now we pray to thee for bliss. Next: HYMN LXV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: NOT to forsake me, I invoke this Indra girt by Maruts, Lord Of magic power who rules with might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Indra with his Marut Friends clave into pieces Vṛtra's bead With hundred-knotted thunderbolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, with Marut Friends grown strong, hath rent asunder Vṛtra, and Released the waters of the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is that Indra who, begirt by Maruts, won the light of heaven That he might drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mighty, impetuous, begirt by Maruts, him who loudly roars, Indra we invocate with songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra begirt by Maruts we invoke after the ancient plan, That he may drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O liberal Indra, Marut-girt, much-lauded Śatakratu, drink The Soma at this sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee, O Indra, Marut-girt, these Soma juices, Thunderer! Are offered from the heart with lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink, Indra, with thy Marut Friends, pressed Soma at the morning rites, Whetting thy thunderbolt with strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Arising in thy might, thy jaws thou shookest, Indra, having quaffed The Soma which the mortar pressed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, both worlds complained to thee when uttering thy fearful roar, What time thou smotest Dasyus dead.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From Indra have I measured out a song eight-footed with nine parts, Delicate, faithful. to the Law. Next: HYMN LXVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SCARCELY was Śatakratu, born when of his Mother he inquired, Who are the mighty? Who are famed?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then Śavasī declared to him Aurṇavābha, Ahīśuva: Son, these be they thou must o’erthrow

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Vṛtra-slayer smote them all as spokes are hammered into naves: The Dasyu-killer waxed in might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then Indra at a single draught drank the contents of thirty pails, Pails that were filled with Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra in groundless realms of space pierced the Gandharva through, that he Might make Brahmans' strength increase.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Down from the mountains Indra shot hither his well-directed shaft: He gained the ready brew of rice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One only is that shaft of thine, with thousand feathers, hundred barbs, Which, Indra, thou hast made thy friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong as the Ṛbhus at thy birth, therewith to those who praise thee, men, And women, bring thou food to eat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By thee these exploits were achieved, the mightiest deeds, abundantly: Firm in thy heart thou settest them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All these things Viṣṇu brought, the Lord of ample stride whom thou hadst sent- A hundred buffaloes, a brew of rice and milk: and Indra, slew the ravening boar

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most deadly is thy bow, successful, fashioned well: good is thine arrow, decked with gold. Warlike and well equipped thine arms are, which increase sweetness for him who drinks the sweet. Next: HYMN LXVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BRING us a thousand, Indra, as our guerdon for the Soma juice: Hundreds of kine, O Hero, bring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring cattle, bring us ornament, bring us embellishment and steeds, Give us, besides, two rings of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And, Bold One, bring in ample store rich jewels to adorn the ear, For thou, Good Lord, art far renowned.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: None other is there for the priest, Hero! but thou, to give him gifts, To win much spoil and prosper him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra can never be brought low, Śakra can never be subdued: He heareth and beholdeth all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He spieth out the wrath of man, he who can never be deceived: Ere blame can come he marketh it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He hath his stomach full of might, the Vṛtra-slayer, Conqueror, The Soma-drinker, ordering all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thee all treasures are combined, Soma all blessed things in thee, Uninjured, easy to bestow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee speeds forth my hope that craves the gift of corn, and kine and gold, Yea, craving horses, speeds to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, through hope in thee alone even this sickle do I grasp. Fill my hand, Maghavan, with all that it can hold of barley cut or gathered up. Next: HYMN LXVIII. Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THIS here is Soma, ne’er restrained, active, all-conquering bursting forth, Ṛṣi and Sage by sapience,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All that is bare he covers o’er, all that is sick he medicines; The blind man sees, the cripple walks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Soma, givest wide defence against the hate of alien men, Hatreds that waste and weaken us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou by thine insight and thy skill, Impetuous One, from heaven and earth Drivest the sinner's enmity.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When to their task they come with zeal, may they obtain the Giver's grace, And satisfy his wish who thirsts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may he find what erst was lost, so may be speed the pious man, And lengthen his remaining life.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gracious, displaying tender love, unconquered, gentle in thy thoughts, Be sweet, O Soma, to our heart.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, terrify us not; strike us not with alarm, O King: Wound not our heart with dazzling flame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When in my dwelling-place I see the wicked enemies of Gods, King, chase their hatred far away, thou Bounteous One, dispel our foes. Next: HYMN LXIX. Indra

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Sarakratu! truely I have made none else my Comforter. Indra; be gracious unto us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou who hast ever aided us kindly of old to win the spoil, As such, O Indra, favour us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What now? As prompter of the poor thou helpest him who sheds the juice. Wilt thou not, Indra, strengthen us?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, help our chariot on, yea, Thunderer, though it lag behind: Give this my car the foremost place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ho there! why sittest thou at case? Make thou my chariot to be first And bring the fame of victory near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Assist our car that seeks the prize. What can be easier for thee? So make thou us victorious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, be firm: a fort art thou. To thine appointed place proceeds The auspicious hymn in season due.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not our portion be disgrace. Broad is the course, the prize is set, The barriers are opened wide.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This thing we wish. that thou mayst take thy fourth, thy sacrificial name. So art thou held to be our Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ekadyu hath exalted you, Immortals: both Goddesses and Gods hath he delighted. Bestow upon him bounty meet for praises. May he, enriched with prayer, come soon and early. Next: HYMN LXX. Indra.
