translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA, God of the mighty arm, gather for us with thy right hand Manifold and nutritious spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We know thee mighty in thy deeds, of mighty bounty, mighty wealth, Mighty in measure, prompt to aid.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hero, when thou art fain to give, neither may Gods nor mortal men Restrain thee like a fearful Bull.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, let us glorify Indra, Lord supreme of wealth, Self-ruling King: In bounty may he harm us not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let prelude sound and following chant so let him hear the Sāman sung, And with his bounty answer us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, with thy right hand bring, and with thy left remember us. Let us not lose our share of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come nigh, O Bold One, boldly bring hither the riches of the churl Who giveth least of all the folk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, the booty which thou hast with holy singers to receive, Even that booty win with us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, thy swiftly-coming spoil, the booty which rejoices all, Sounds quick in concert with our hopes. Next: HYMN LXXI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HASTE forward to us from afar, or, Vṛtra-slayer, from anear, To meet the offering to the meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong are the Soma-draughts; come nigh: the juices fill thee with delight: Drink boldly even as thou art wont'.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Joy, Indra, in the strengthening food et it content thy wish and thought, And be delightful to thine heart.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us thou who hast no foe: we call thee down to hymns of praise, In heaven's sublimest realm of light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma here expressed with stones and dressed with milk for thy carouse, Indra, is offered up to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Graciously, Indra, hear my call. Come and obtain the draught, and sate Thyself with juices blent with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Soma, Indra, which is shed in chalices and vats for thee, Drink thou, for thou art Lord thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Soma seen within the vats, as in the flood the Moon is seen, Drink thou, for thou art Lord thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That which the Hawk brought in his claw, inviolate, through the air to thee, Drink thou, for thou art Lord thereof. Next: HYMN LXXII. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE choose unto ourselves that high protection of the Mighty Gods That it may help and succour us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May they be ever our allies, Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman, Far-seeing Gods who prosper us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye furtherers of holy Law, transport us safe o’er many woes, As over water-floods in ships.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dear wealth be Aryaman to us, Varuṇa dear wealth meet for praise: Dear wealth we choose unto ourselves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Sovrans of dear wealth are ye, Ādityas, not of sinner's wealth, Ye sapient Gods who slay the foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We in our homes, ye Bounteous Ones, and while we journey on the road, Invoke you, Gods, to prosper us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Regard us, Indra, Viṣṇu, here, ye Aśvins and the Marut host, Us who are kith and kin to you.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Bounteous Ones, from time of old we here set forth our brotherhood, Our kinship in. the Mother's womb.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then come with Indra for your chief, as early day, ye Bounteous Gods Yea, 1 address you now for this. Next: HYMN LXXIII. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: AGNI, your dearest Guest, I laud, him who is loving as a friend, Who brings us riches like a car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom as a far-foreseeing Sage the Gods have, from the olden time, Established among mortal men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou, Most Youthful God, protect the men who offer, hear their songs, And of thyself preserve their seed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What is the praise wherewith, O God, Aṅgiras, Agni, Son of Strength, We, after thine own wish and thought,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May serve thee, O thou Child of Power, and with what sacrifice's plan? What prayer shall I now speak to thee?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our God, make all of us to dwell in happy habitations, and Reward our songs with spoil and wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of the house, what plenty fills the songs which thou inspirest now, Thou whose hymn helps to win the kine?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hirn Wise and Strong they glorify, the foremost Champion in the fray, And mighty in his dwelling-place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, he dwells in rest and peace who smites and no one smites again: With hero sons he prospers well Next: HYMN LXXIV. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To this mine invocation, O ye Aśvins, ye Nāsatyas, come, To drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This laud of mine, ye Aśvins Twain, and this mine invitation hear, To drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here Kṛṣṇa is invoking you, O Aśvins, Lords of ample wealth. To drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: List, Heroes, to the singer's call, the call of Kṛṣṇa lauding you, To drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Chiefs, to the sage who sings your praise grant an inviolable home, To drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to the worshipper's abode, Aśvins, who here is lauding you, To drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yoke to the firmly jointed car the ass which draws you, Lords of wealth. To drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come hither, Aśvins, on your car of triple form with triple seat, To drink the savoury Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Aśvins, O Nāsatyas, now accept with favouring grace my songs, To drink the savoury Soma juice. Next: HYMN LXXV. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YE Twain are wondrous strong, well-skilled in arts that heal, both bringers of delight, ye both won Dakṣa's praise. Viśvaka calls on you as such to save his life. Break ye not off our friendship, come and set me free.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: How shall he praise you now who is distraught in mind? Ye Twain give wisdom for the gainof what is good. Viśvaka calls on you as such to save his life. Break ye not off our friendship, come and set me free.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Already have ye Twain, possessors of great wealth, prospered Viṣṇāpū thus for gain of what is good. Viśvaka calls on you as such to save his life. Break ye not off our friendship, come and set me free.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And that Impetuous Hero, winner of the spoil, though he is far away, we call to succour us, Whose gracious favour, like a father's, is most sweet. Break ye not off our friendship, come and set me free.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: About the holy Law toils Savitar the God the horn of holy Law hath he spread far and wide. The holy Law hath quelled even mighty men of war. Break ye not off our ftiendship, come and act me free. Next: HYMN LXXVI. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SPLENDID, O Aśvins, is your praise. Come fountain-like, to pour the stream. Of the sweet juice effused-dear is it, Chiefs, in heaven-drink like two wild bulls at a pool.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink the libation rich in sweets, O Aśvins Twain: sit. Heroes, on the sacred grass. Do ye with joyful heart in the abode of man preserve his life by means of wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Priyamedhas bid you come with all the succours that are yours. Come to his house whose holy grass is trimmed, to dear sacrifice at the morning rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink ye the Soma rich in meath, ye Aśvins Twain: sit gladly on the sacred grass. So, waxen mighty, to our eulogy from heaven come ye as wild-bulls to the pool.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come to us, O ye Aśvins, now with steeds of many a varied hue, Ye Lords of splendour, wondrous, borne on paths of gold, drink Soma, ye who strengthen Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For we the priestly singers, fain tohymn your praise, invoke you for the gain of strength. So, wondrous, fair, and famed for great deeds come to us, through our hymn, Aśvins, when ye hear. Next: HYMN LXXVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As cows low to their calves in stalls, so with our songs we glorify This Indra, even your Wondrous God who checks attack, who joys in the delicious juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Celestial, bounteous Giver, girt about with might, rich, mountain-like, in precious things, Him swift we seek. for foodful booty rich in kine, brought hundredfold and thousandfold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, the strong and lofty hills are powerless to bar thy way. None stay that act of thine when thou wouldst fain give wealth to one like me who sings thy praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A Warrior thou by strength, wisdom, and wondrous deed, in might excellest all that is. Hither may this our hymn attract thee to our help, the hymn which Gotamas have made.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For in thy might thou stretchest out beyond the boundaries of heaven. The earthly region, Indra, comprehends thee not. After thy Godhead hast thou waxed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Maghavan, thou honourest the worshipper, no one is there to stay thy wealth. Most liberal Giver thou, do thou inspire our song of praise, that we may win the spoil. Next: HYMN LXXVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra sing the lofty hymn, Maruts that slays the Vṛtras best. Whereby the Holy Ones created for the God the light divine that ever wakes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra who quells the curse blew curses far away, and then in splendour came to us. Indra, refulgent with thy Marut host! the Gods strove eagerly to win thy love.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing to your lofty Indra, sing, Maruts, a holy hymn of praise. Let Śatakratu, Vṛtra-slayer, kill the foe with hundred-knotted thunderbolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aim and fetch boldly forth, O thou whose heart is bold: great glory will be thine thereby. In rapid torrent let the mother waters spread. Slay Vṛtra, win the light of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thou, unequalled Maghavan, wast born to smite the Vṛtras dead, Thou spreadest out the spacious earth and didst support and prop the heavens.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Theri was the sacrifice produced for thee, the laud, and song of joy, Thou in thy might surpassest all, all that now is and yet shall be.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Raw kine thou filledst with ripe milk. Thou madest Sūrya rise to heaven., Heat him as milk is heated with pure Sāma hymns, great joy to him who loves the song. Next: HYMN LXXIX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MAY Indra, who in every fight must be invoked, be near to us. May the most mighty Vṛtra-slayer, meet for praise, come to libations and to hymns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art the best of all in sending bounteous gifts, true art thou, lordly in thine act. We claim alliance with the very Glorious One, yea, with the Mighty Son of Strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Prayers unsurpassed are offered up to thee the Lover of the Song. Indra, Lord of Bay Steeds, accept these fitting hymns, hymns which we have thought out for thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou, O Maghavan, art truthful, ne’er subdued and bringest many a Vṛtra low. As such, O Mightiest Lord, Wielder of Thunder, send wealth hither to the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, thou art far-renowned, impetuous, O Lord of Strength. Alone thou slayest with the guardian of mankind resistless never-conquered foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such we seek thee now, O Asura, thee most wise, craving thy bounty as our share. Thy sheltering defence is like a mighty cloak. So may thy glories reach to us. Next: HYMN LXXX. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: DOWN to the stream a maiden came, and found the Soma by the way. Bearing it to her home she said, For Indra will I press thee out, for Śakra will I press thee out.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou roaming yonder, little man, beholding every house in turn, Drink thou this Soma pressed with teeth, accompanied with grain and curds, with cake of meal and song of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fain would we learn to know thee well, nor yet can we attain to thee. Still slowly and in gradual drops, O Indu, unto Indra flow.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Will he not help and work for us? Will he not make us wealthier? Shall we not, hostile to our lord, unite ourselves to Indra now?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, cause to sprout again three places, these which I declare,— My father's head, his cultured field, and this the part below my waist.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make all of these grow crops of hair, you cultivated field of ours, My body, and my father's head.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cleansing Apala, Indra! thrice, thou gavest sunlike skin to her, Drawn, Śatakratu! through the hole of car, of wagon, and of yoke. Next: HYMN LXXXI. Indra

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INVITE ye Indra with a song to drink your draught of Soma juice, All-conquering Śatakratu, most munificent of all who live.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lauded by many, much-invoked, leader of song, renowned of old: His name is Indra, tell it forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra the Dancer be to us the giver of abundant strength: May he, the mighty, bring it near.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra whose jaws are strong hath drunk of worshipping Sudaksa's draught, The Soma juice with barley mixt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call Indra loudly with your songs of praise to drink the Soma juice. For this is what augments his stiength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When he hath drqnk its gladdening drops, the God with vigour of a God Hath far surpassed all things that are.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou speedest down to succour us this ever-conquering God of yours, Him who is drawn to all our songs

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Warrior not to he restrained, the Soma-drinker ne’er o’erthrown, The Chieftain of resistless might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, send us riches, thou Omniscient, worthy of our praise: Help us in the decisive fray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even thence, O Indra, come to us with food that gives a hundred powers, With food that gives a thousand powers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We sought the wisdom of the wise. Śakra, Kine-giver, Thunder-armed! May we with steeds o’ercome in fight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We make thee, Śatakratu, find enjoyment in the songs we sing. Like cattle in the pasture lands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Śatakratu, Thunder-armed, all that we craved, as men are wont, All that we hoped, have we attained.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those, Son of Strength, are come to thee who cherish wishes in their hearts O Indra, none excelleth thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, Hero, guard us with thy care, with thy most liberal providence, Speedy, and terrible to foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Śatakratu Indra, now rejoice with that carouse of thine Which is most splendid of them all

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even, Indra, that carouse which slays the Vṛtras best, most widely famed, Best giver of thy power and might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For that which is thy gift we know, true Soma-drinker, Thunder-armed, Mighty One, amid all the folk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra, Lover of Carouse, loud be our songs about the juice: Let poets sing the song of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We summon Indra to the draught, irl whom all glories rest, in whom The seven communities rejoice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At the Trikadrukas the Gods span sacrifice that stirs the mind: Let our songs aid and prosper it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let the drops pass within thee as the rivers flow into the sea: O fndra, naught excelleth thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, wakeful Hero, by thy might hast taken food of Soma juice, Which, Indra, is within thee now.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, Vṛtra-slayer, let Soma be ready for thy maw, The drops be ready for thy forms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now Srutakaksa sings his song that cattle and the steed may come, That Indra's very self may come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here, Indra, thou art ready by our Soma juices shed for thee, Śakra, at hand that thou mayst give.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even from far away our songs reach thee, O Caster of the Stone: May we come very close to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For so thou art the hero's Friend, a Hero, too, art thou, and strong: So may thine heart be won to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So hath the offering, wealthiest Lord, been paid by all the worshippers: So dwell thou, Indra, even with me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Be not thou like a slothfid priest, O Lord of spoil and wealth: rejoice In the pressed Soma blent with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, let not ill designs surround us in the sunbeams' light: This may we gain with thee for Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With thee to help us, Indra, let us answer all our enemies: For thou art ours and we are thine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, the poets and thy friends, faithful to thee, shall loudly sing Thy praises as they follow thee. Next: HYMN LXXXII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SURYA, thou mountest up to meet the Hero famous for his wealth, Who hurls the bolt and works for man

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him who with might of both his arms brake nine-and-ninety castles down, Slew Vṛtra and smote Ahi dead.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Indra is our gracious Friend. He sends us in a full broad stream Riches in horses, kine, and corn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whatever, Vṛtra-slayer! thou, Sūrya, hast risen upon to-day, Tbat, Indra, all is in thy power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, Mighty One, Lord of the brave, thou thinkest thus, I shall not die, That thought of thine is true indeed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Indra, goest unto all Soma libations shed for thee, Both far away and near at hand.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We make this Indra very strong to strike the mighty Vṛtra dead: A vigorous Hero shall he be.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra was made for giving, set, most mighty, o’er the joyous draught. Bright, meet for Soma, famed in song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By song as ’twere, the powerful bolt which none may parry was prepared Lofty, invincible he grew.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, Song-lover, lauded, make even in the wilds fair ways for us, Whenever, Maghavan, thou wilt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou whose commandment and behest of sovran sway none disregards, Neither audacious man nor God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And both these Goddesses, Earth, Heaven, Lord of the beauteous helm! revere Thy might which no one may resist.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou in the black cows and the red and in the cows with spotted skin This white milk hast deposited.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When in their terror all the Gods shrank from the Dragon's furious might, Fear of the monster fell on them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then he was my Defender, then, Invincible, whose foe is not, The Vṛtra-slayer showed his might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him your best Vṛtra-slayer, him the famous Champion of mankind I urge to great munificence,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To come, Much-lauded! Many-named with this same thought that longs for milk, Whene’er the Soma juice is shed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Much-honoured by libations, may the Vṛtra-slayer wake for us: May Śakra listen to our prayers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Hero, with that aid dost thou delight us, with what succour bring Riches to those who worship thee?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With whose libation joys the Strong, the Hero with his team who quells The foe, to drink the Soma juice?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rejoicing in thy spirit bring thousandfold opulence to us: Enrich thy votary with gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These juices with their wedded wives flow to enjoyment lovingly: To waters speeds the restless one.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Presented strengthening gifts have sent Indra away at sacrifice, With might, onto the cleansing bath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These two who share his feast, Bay Steeds with golden manes, shall bring him to The banquet that is laid for him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thee, O Lord of Light, are shed these Soma-drops, and grass is strewn Bring Indra to his worshippers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra give thee skill, and lights of heaven, wealth to his votary And priests who praise him: laud ye him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Śatakratu, wondrous strength and all our lauds I bring to thee: Be gracious to thy worshippers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring to us all things excellent, O Śatakratu, food and strength: For, Indra, thou art kind to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: § O Śatakratu, bring to us all blessings, all felicity: Fbr, Indra, thou art kind to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bearing the Soma juice we call, best Vṛtra-slayer, unto thee: For, Indra, thou art kind to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Lord of rapturous, joys, to our libation with thy Bay Steeds, come To our libation with thy Steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Known as best Vṛtra-slayer erst, as Indra Śatakratu, come With Bay Steeds to the juice we shed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vṛtra-slayer, thou art he who drinks these drops of Soma: come With Bay Steeds to the juice we shed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra give, to aid us, wealth handy that rules the Skilful Ones: Yea, may the Strong give potent wealth. Next: HYMN LXXXIII. Maruts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE Cow, the famous Mother of the wealthy Maruts, pours her milk: Both horses of the cars are yoked,—

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She in whose bosom all the Gods, and Sun and Moon for men to see, Maintain their everlasting Laws.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This all the pious sing to us, and sacred poets evermore: The Maruts to the Soma-draught

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here is the Soma ready pressed of this the Maruts drink, of this Self-luminous the Aśvins drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Of this, moreover, purified, set in three places, procreant, Drink Varuṇa, Mitra, Aryaman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And Indra, like the Herald Priest, desirous of the milky juice, At early morn will quaff thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When have the Princes gleamed and shone through waters as through troops of foes'? When hasten they whose might ispure?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What favour do I claim this day of you great Deities, you who are Wondrously splendid in yourselves?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: 1 call, to drink the Soma, those Maruts who spread all realms of earth And luminous regions of the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: You, even such, pure in your might, you, O ye Maruts, I invoke From heaven to drink this Somajuice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Maruts, those who have sustained and propped the heavens and earth apart, I call to drink this Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That vigorous band of Maruts that abidetb in the mountains, I Invoke to drink this Soma juice. Next: HYMN LXXXIV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SONG-LOVER! like a charioteer come songs to thee when Soma flows. O Indra, they have called to thee as mother-kine unto their calves.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright juices bitherward have sped thee, Indra, Lover of the Song. Drink, Indra, of this flowing sap: in every house ’tis set for thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drink Soma to inspirit thee, juice, Indra, which the Falcon brought: For thou art King and Sovran Lord of all the families of men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, hear Tirasci's call, the call of him who serveth thee. Satisfy him with wealth of kine and valiant offspring: Great art thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For he, O Indra, hath produced for thee the newest gladdening song, A hymn that springs from careful thought, ancient, and full of sacred truth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That Indra will we laud whom songs and hymns of praise have magnified. Striving to win, we celebrate his many deeds of hero might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come now and let us glorify pure Indra with pure Sāma hymns. Let the pure milky draught delight him strengthened by pure songs of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, come thou pure to us, with pure assistance, pure thyself. Pure, send thou riches down to us, and, meet for Soma, pure, be glad.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, pure, vouchsafe us wealth, and, pure, enrich the worshipper. Pure, thou dost strike the Vṛtras dead, and strivest, pure, to win the spoil. Next: HYMN LXXXV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR him the Mornings made their courses longer, and Nights with pleasant voices spake to Indra. For him the Floods stood still, the Seven Mothers, Streams easy for the heroes to pass over.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Darter penetrated, though in trouble, thrice-seven close-pressed ridges of the mountains. Neither might God nor mortal man accomplish what the Strong Hero wrought in full-grown vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mightiest force is Indra's bolt of iron when firmly grasped in both the arms of Indra. His head and mouth have powers that pass all others, and all his people hasten near to listen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: 1 count thee as the Holiest of the Holy, the caster-down of what hath ne’er been shaken. I count thee as the Banner of the heroes, I count thee as the Chief of all men living.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time, O Indra, in thine arms thou tookest thy wildly rushing bolt to Slay the Dragon, The mountains roared, the cattle loudly bellowed, the Brahmans with their hymns drew nigh to Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us praise him who made these worlds and creatures, all things that after him sprang into being. May we win Mitra with our songs, and Indra, and. wait upon our Lord with adoration.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flying in terror from the snort of Vṛtra, all Deities who were thy friends forsook thee. So, Indra, be thy friendship with the Maruts: in all these battles thou shalt be the victor.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thrice-sixty Maruts, waxing strong, were with thee, like piles of beaming light, worthy of worship. We come to thee: grant us a happy portion. Let us adore thy might with this oblation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A sharpened weapon is the host of Maruts. Who, Indra, dares withstand thy bolt of thunder? Weaponless are the Asuras, the godless: scatter them with thy wheel, Impetuous Hero.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the Strong and Mighty, most auspicious, send up the beAuteous hymn for sake of cattle. Lay oa his body many songs for Indra invoked with song, for will not he regard. them?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him, the Mighty, who accepts laudation, send forth thy thought as by a boat o’er rivers, Stir with thy hymn the body of the Famous and Dearest One, for will not he regard it?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Serve him with gifts of thine which Indra welcomes: praise with fair praise, invite him with thine homage. Draw near, O singer, and refrain from outcry. Make thy voice heard, for will not he regard it?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Black Drop sank in Amsumati's bosom, advancing with ten thousand round about it. Indra with might longed for it as it panted: the hero-hearted laid aside his weapons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: 1 saw the Drop in the far distance moving, on the slope bank of Amsumati's river, Like a black cloud that sank into the water. Heroes, I send you forth. Go, fight in battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And then the Drop in Amsumati's bosom, splendid with light, assumed its proper body; And Indra, with Bṛhaspati to aid him, conquered the godless tribes that came against him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then, at thy birth, thou wast the foeman, Indra, of those the seven who ne’er had met a rival. The hidden Pair, the Heaven and Earth, thou foundest, and to the mighty worlds thou gavest pleasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, Thunder-armed! thou with thy bolt of thunder didst boldly smite that power which none might equal; With weapons broughtest low the migbt of Śuṣṇa, and, Indra, foundest by thy strength the cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then wast thou, Chieftain of all living mortals, the very mighty slayer of the Vṛtras. Then didst thou set the obstructed rivers flowing, and win the floods that were enthralled by Dāsas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Most wise is he, rejoicing in libations, splendid as day, resistless in his anger. He only doth great deeds, the only Hero, sole Vṛtra-slayer he, with none beside him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra is Vṛtra's slayer, man's sustainer: he must be called; with fair praise let us call him. Maghavan is our Helper, our Protector, giver of spoil and wealth to make us famous.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Indra, Vṛtra-slayer, this Ṛbhukṣan, even at his birth, was meet for invocation. Doer of many deeds for man's advantage, like Soma quaffed, for friends we must invoke him. Next: HYMN LXXXVI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O INDRA, Lord of Light, what joys thou broughtest from the Asuras, Prosper therewith, O Maghavan, him who lauds that deed, and those whose grass is trimmed for thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The unwasting share of steeds and kine which, Indra, thou hast fast secured, Grant to the worshipper who presses Soma and gives guerdon, not unto the churl.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The riteless, godless man who sleeps, O Indra, his unbroken steep,— May he by following his own devices die. Hide from him wealth that nourishes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether, O Śakra, thou be far, or, Vṛtra-slayer, near at hand, Thence by heaven-reaching songs he who hath pressed the juice invites thee with thy long-maned Steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whether thou art in heaven's bright sphere, or in the basin of the sea; Whether, chief Vṛtra-slayer, in some place on earth, or in the firmament, approach.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou Soma-drinker, Lord of Strength, beside our flowing Soma juice Delight us with thy bounty rich in pleasantness, O Indra, with abundant wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, turn us not away: be the companion of our feast. For thou art our protection, yea, thou art our kin: O Indra, turn us not away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sit down with us, O Indra, sit beside the juice to drink the meath. Show forth great favour to the Singer, Maghavan; Indra, with us, beside the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Caster of the Stone, nor Gods nor mortals have attained to thee. Thou in thy might surpassest all that hath been made: the Gods have not attained to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Of one accord they made and formed for kingship Indra, the Hero who in all encounters overcometh, Most eminent for power, destroyer in the conflict, fierce and exceeding strong, stalwart and full of vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bards joined in song to Indra so that he might drink the Soma juice, The Lord of Light, that he whose laws stand fast might aid with power and with the help he gives.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tle holy sages form a ring, looking and singing to the Ram. Inciters, full of vigour, not to he deceived, are with the chanters, nigh to bear.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loudly I call that Indra, Maghavan the Mighty, who evermore possesses power, ever resistless. Holy, most liberal, may he lead us on to riches, and, Thunder-armed, make all our pathways pleasant for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou knowest well, O Śakra, thou Most Potent, with thy strength, Indra, to destroy these castles. Before thee, Thunder-armed! all beings tremble: the heavens and earth before thee shake with terror,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May thy truth, Indra, Wondrous Hero be my guard: bear me o’er much woe, Thunderer! as over floods. When, Indra, wilt thou honour us with opulence, all-nourishing and much-to-be. desired, O King? Next: HYMN LXXXVII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra sing a Sāma hymn, a lofty song to Lofty Sage, To him who guards the Law, inspired, and fain for praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Indra, art the Conqueror: thou gavest splendour to the Sun. Maker of all things, thou art Mighty and All-God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Radiant with light thou wentest to the sky, the luminous realm of heaven. ne Deities, Indra strove to win thee for their Friend.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come unto us, O Indra, dear, still conquering, unconcealable, Vast as a mountain spread on all sides, Lord of Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O truthful Soma-drinker, thou art mightier than both the worlds. Thou strengthenest him who pours libation, Lord of Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou art he, O Indra, wiio stormeth all castles of the foe, Slayer of Dasyus, man's Supporter, Lord of Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now have we, Indra, Friend of Song, sent our great wishes forth to thee, Coming like floods that follow floods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As rivers swell the ocean, so, Hero, our prayers increase thy might, Though of thyself, O Thunderer, waxing day by day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With holy song mey bind to the broad wide-yoked car the Bay Steeds of the rapid God, Bearers of Indra, yoked by word.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, bring great strength to us, bring valour, Śatakratu, thou most active, bring A hero conquering in war.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, gracious Śatakratu, thou hast ever been a Mother and a Sire to us, So now for bliss we pray to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To thee, Strong, Much-invoked, who showest forth thy strength, O Śatakratu, do I speak: So grant thou us heroic strength. Next: HYMN LXXXVIII. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O THUNDERER, zealous worshippers gave thee drink this time yesterday. So, Indra, listen here to those who bring the laud: come near unto our dwellingplace.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of Bay Steeds, fair-helmed, rejoice thee: this we crave. Here the disposers wait on thee. Thy loftiest glories claim our lauds beside the juice, O Indra, Lover of the Song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Turning, as ’twere, to meet the Sun, enjoy from Indra all good things. When he who will be born is born with power we look to treasures as our heritage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise him who sends us wealth, whose bounties injure none: good are the gifts which Indra. grants. He is not worth with one who satisfies his wish: he turns his mind to giving boons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou in thy battles, Indra, art subduer of all hostile bands. Father art thou, aIl-conquering, cancelling the curse, thou victor of the vanquisher.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Earth and Heaven clung close to thy victorious might as to their calf two mother-cows. When thou attackest Vṛtra all the hostile bands shrink and faint, Indra, at thy wrath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring to your aid the Eternal One, who shoots and none may shoot at him, Inciter, swift, victorious, best of Charioteers. Tugrya's unvanquished Strengthener;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Arranger of things unarranged, e’en Śatakratu, source of might, Indra, the Friend of all, for succour we invoke, Guardian of treasure, sendjng wealth. Next: HYMN LXXXIX Indra. Vāk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I MOVE before thee here present in person, and all the Deities follow behind me. When, Indra, thou securest me my portion, with me thou shalt perform heroic actions.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The food of meath in foremost place I give thee, thy Soma shall be pressed, thy share appointed. Thou on my right shalt be my friend and comrade: then shall we two smite dead full many a foeman.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Striving for strength bring forth a laud to Indra, a truthful hymn if he in truth existeth. One and another say, There is no Indra. Who hath beheld him? Whom then shall we honour?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here am I, look upon me here, O singer. All that existeth 1 surpass in greatness. The Holy Law's commandments make me mighty. Rending with strength I rend the worlds asunder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the Law's lovers mounted and ap. proached me as 1 sate lone upon the dear sky's summit. Then spake my spirit to the heart within me, My friends have cried unto me with their children.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All these thy deeds must be declared at Soma-feasts, wrought, Indra, Bounteous Lord, for him who sheds the juice, When thou didst open wealth heaped up by many, brought from far away to Sarablia, the Ṛṣi's kin.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now run ye forth your several ways: he is not here who kept you back. For hath not Indra sunk his bolt deep down in Vṛtra's vital part?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On-rushing with the speed of thought within the iron fort he pressed: The Falcon went to heaven and brought the Soma to the Thunderer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Deep in the ocean lies the bolt with waters compassed round about, And in continuous onward flow the floods their tribute bring to it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When, uttering words which no one comprehended, Vāk, Queen of Gods, the Gladdener, was seated, The heaven's four regions drew forth drink and vigour: now whither hath her noblest portion vanished?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Deities generated Vāk the Goddess, and animals of every figure speak her. May she, the Gladdener, yielding food and vigour, the Milch-cow Vāk, approach us meetly lauded.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Step forth with wider stride, my comrade Viṣṇu; make room, Dyaus, for the leaping of the lightning. Let us slay Vṛtra, let us free the rivers let them flow loosed at the command of Indra. Next: HYMN XC. Various.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: YEA, specially that mortal man hath toiled for service of the Gods, Who quickly hath brought near Mitra and Varuṇa. to share his sacrificial gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Supreme in sovran power, far-sighted, Chiefs and Kings, most swift to hear from far away, Both, wondrously, set them in motion as with arms, in company with Sūrya's beams.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The rapid messenger who runs before you, Mitra-Varuṇa, with iron head, swift to the draught,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He whom no man may question, none may summon back, who stands not still for colloquy,— From hostile clash with him keep ye us safe this day: keep us in safety with your arms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Aryaman and Mitra sing a reverent song, O pious one, A pleasant hymn that shall protect to Varuṇa: sing forth a laud unto the Kings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The true, Red Treasure they have sent, one only Son born of the Three. They, the Immortal Ones, never deceived, survey the families of mortal men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: My songs are lifted up, and acts most splendid are to be performed. Come hither, ye Nāsatyas, with accordant mind, to meet and to enjoy my gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lords of great wealth, when we invoke your bounty which no demon checks, Both of you, furthering our eastward-offcred praise, come, Chiefs whom Jamadagni lauds!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Vāyu, drawn by fair hymns, to our sacrifice that reaches heaven. Poured on the middle of the strainingcloth, and cooked, this bright drink hath been offered ilice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He comes by straightest paths, as ministering Priest, to taste the sacrificial gifts. Then, Lord of harnessed teams I drink of the twofold draught, bright Soma mingled with the milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Verily, Sūrya, thou art great; truly, Āditya, thou art great. As thou art great indeed, thy greatness is admired: yea, verily, thou, God, art great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, Sūrya, thou art great in fame thou evermore, O God, art great. Thou by thy greatness art the Gods’ High Priest, divine, far-spread unconquerable light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: She yonder, bending lowly down, clothed in red hues and rich in rays, Is seen, advancing as it were with various tints, amid the ten surrounding arms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Past and gone are three mortal generations: the fourth and last into the Sun hath entered. He mid the worlds his lofty place hath taken. Into green plants is gone the Purifying.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Rudras' Mother, Daughter of the Vasus, centre of nectar, the Ādityas’ Sister- To folk who understand will 1 proclaim it-injure not Aditi, the Cow, the sinless.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Weak-minded men have as a cow adopted me who came hither from the Gods, a Goddess, Who, skilled in eloquence, her voice uplifteth, who standeth near at hand with all devotions. Next: HYMN XCI. Agni.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LORD of the house, Sage, ever young, high power of life, O Agni, God, Thou givest to thy worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So with our song that prays and serves, attentive, Lord of spreading light, Agni, bring hitherward the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, Ever-Youthful One, with thee, best Furtherer, as our ally, We overcome, to win the spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Aurva Bhṛgu used, as Apnavāna used, I call the pure Agni who clothes him with the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: 1 call the Sage who sounds like wind, the Might that like Parjanya roars, Agni who clothes him with the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Savitar's productive Power, as him who sends down bliss, I call Agni who clothes him with the sea.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither, for powerful kirship, I call Agni, him Who prospers you, Most frequent at our solemn rites

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That through this famed One's power, he may stand by us even as Tvaṣṭar comes Unto the forms that must he shaped.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Agni is the Lord supreme above all glories mid the Gods: May he come nigh to us with strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here praise ye him the most renowned of all the ministering Priests, Agni, the Chief at sacrifice;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Piercing, with purifying flame, enkindled in our homes, most high, Swiftest to hear from far away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sage, laud the Mighty One who wins the spoil of victory like a steed, And, Mitra like, unites the folk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Still turning to their aim in thee, the oblation-bearer's sister hymns Have come to thee before the wind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The waters find their place in him, for whom the threefold sacred grass Is spread unbound, unlimited.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The station of the Bounteous God hath, through his aid which none impair, A pleasant aspect like the Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Blazing with splendour, Agni, God, through pious gifts of sacred oil, Bring thou the Gods and worship them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Gods as mothers brought thee forth, the Immortal Sage, O Aṅgiras, The bearer of our gifts to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise Agni, Gods established thee, the Seer, noblest messenger, As bearer of our sacred gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: No cow have I to call mine own, no axe at hand wherewith to work, Yet what is here I bring to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, whatsoever be the fuel that we lay for thee, Be pleased therewith, Most Youthful God

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That which the white-ant cats away, that over which the emmet crawls- May all of this be oil to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When he enkindles Agni, man should with his heart attend the song: I with the priests have kindled him. Next: HYMN XCII. Agni

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THAT noblest Furtherer hath appeared, to whom men bring their holy works. Our songs of praise have risen aloft to Agni who was barn to give the Ārya strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni of Divodāsa turned, as ’twere in majesty, to the Gods. Onward he sped along the mother earth, and took his station in the height of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him before whom the people shrink when he performs his glorious deeds, Him who wins thousands at the worship of the Gods, himself, that Agni, serve with son s.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mortal man whom thou wouldst lead to opulence, O Vasu, he who brings thee gifts. He, Agni, wins himself a hero singing lauds, yea, one who feeds a thousand men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He with the steed wins spoil even in the fenced fort, and gains imperishable fame. In thee, O Lord of wealth, continually we lay all precious offerings to the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him who dealeth out all wealth, who is the cheerful Priest of men, To him, like the first vessels filled with savoury juice, to Agni go the songs of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Votaries, richly-gifted, deck him with their songs, even as the steed who draws the car. On both, Strong Lord of men! on child and grandson pour the bounties which our nobles give.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing forth to him, the Holy, most munificent, sublime with his refulgent glow, To Agni, ye Upastutas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Worshipped with gifts, enkindled, splendid, Maghavan shall win himself heroic fame. And will not his most newly shown benevolence come to us with abundant strength?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Priest, presser of the juice! praise now the dearest Guest of all our friends, Agni, the driver of the cars.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who, finder-out of treasures open and concealed, bringeth them hither, Holy One; Whose waves, as in a cataract, are hard to pass, when he, through song, would win him strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the noble Guest, Agni, be wroth with us: by many a man his praise is sung, Good Herald, skilled in sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Vasu, Agni, let not them be harmed who come in any way with lauds to thee. Even the lowly, skilled in rites, with offered gifts, seeketh thee for the envoy's task.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Friend of the Maruts, Agni, come with Rudras to the Soma-draught, To Sobhar's fair song of praise, and be thou joyful in the light. VALAKHILYA Next: HYMN I. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: TO you will I sing Indra's praise who gives good gifts as well we know; The praise of Maghavan who, rich in treasure, aids his singers with wealth thousandfold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As with a hundred hosts, he rushes boldly on, and for the offerer slays his foes. As from a mountain flow the water-brooks, thus flow his gifts who feedeth many a one.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The drops effused, the gladdening draughts, O Indra, Lover of the Son As waters seek the lake where they are wont to rest, fill thee, for bounty, Thunderer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The matchless draught that strengthens and gives eloquence, the sweetest of the meath drink thou, That in thy joy thou maysi scatter thy gifts o’er us, plenteously, even as the dust.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come quickly to our laud, urged on by Soma-pressers like a horse- Laud, Godlike Indra, which milch-kine make sweet for thee: with Kaṇva's sons are gifts for thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With homage have we sought thee as a Hero, strong, preeminent, with unfailing wealth. O Thunderer, as a plenteous spring pours forth its stream, so, Indra, flow our songs to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: If now thou art at sacrifice, or if thou art upon the earth, Come thence, high-thoughted! to our sacrifice with the Swift, come, Mighty with the Mighty Ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The active, fleet-foot, tawny Coursers that are thine are swift to victory, like the Wind, Wherewith thou goest round to visit Manus' seed, wherewith all heaven is visible.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, from thee so great we crave prosperity in wealth of kine, As, Maghavan, thou favouredst Medhyātithi, and, in the fight, Nipatithi.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As, Maghavan, to Kaṇva, Trasadasyu, and to Paktha and Dasavraja; As, Indra, to Gosarya and Ṛjiśvan, thou vouchsafedst wealth in kine and gold. Next: HYMN II. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SAKRA I praise, to win his aid, far-famed, exceeding bountiful, Who gives, as ’twere in thousands, precious wealth to him who sheds the juice and worships him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Arrows with hundred points, unconquerable, are this Indra's n-dghty arms in war. He streams on liberal worshippers like a hill with springs, when juices poured have gladdened him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the flowing Soma-drops have gladdened with their taste the Friend, Like water, gracious Lord! were my libations made, like milch-kine to the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the peerless, who is calling you to give you aid, forth flow the drops of pleasant meath. The Soloa-drops which call on thee, O gracious Lord, have brought thee to our hymn of praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He rushes hurrying like a steed to Soma that adorns our rite, Which hymns make sweet to thee, lover of pleasant food. The call to Paura thou dost love.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Praise the strong, grasping Hero, winner of the spoil, ruling supreme oer mighty wealth. Like a full spring, O Thunderer, from thy store hast thou poured on the worshipper evermore.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now whether thou be far away, or in the heavens, or on the earth, O Indra, mighty- thoughted, harnessing thy Bays, come Lofty with the Lofty Ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bays who draw thy chariot, Steeds who injure none, surpass the wind's impetuous strength- With whom thou silencest the enemy of man, with whon; thou goest round the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O gracious Hero, may we learn anew to know thee as thou art: As in decisive fight thou holpest Etaśa, or Vaśa 'gainst Dasavraja,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As, Maghavan, to Kaṇva at the sacred feast, to Dirghanitha thine home-friend, As to Gosarya thou, Stone-darter, gavest wealth, give me a gold-bright stall of kine. Next: HYMN III. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As with Manu Samvarani, Indra, thou drankest Soma juice, And, Maghavan, with Nipatithi, Medbyatithi, with Pustigu and Srustigu,—

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: T'he son of Prsadvana was Praskaniva's host, who lay decrepit and forlorn. Aided by thee the Ṛṣi Dasyave-vrka strove to obtain thousands of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Call hither with thy newest song Indra who lacks not hymns of praise, Him who observes and knows, inspirer of the sage, him who seems eager to enjoy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He unto whom they sang the seven-headed hymn, three-parted, in the loftiest place, He sent his thunder down on all these living things, and so displayed heroic might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We invocate that Indra who bestoweth precious things on us. Now do we know his newest favour; may we gain a stable that is full of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He whom thou aidest, gracious Lord, to give again, obtains great wealth to nourish him. We with our Soma ready, Lover of the Song! call, Indra Maghavan, on thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ne’er art thou fruitless, Indra ne’er dost thou desert the worshipper But now, O Maghavan, thy bounty as a God is poured forth ever more and more.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who hath. overtaken Krvi with his might, and silenced Śuṣṇa with deathbolts,— When he supported yonder heaven and spread it out, then first the son of earth was born.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Good Lord of wealth is he to whom all Āryas, Dāsas here belong. Directly unto thee, the pious Ruśama Paviru, is that wealth brought nigh.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In zealous haste the singers have sung forth a song distilling oil and rich in sweets. Riches have spread among us and heroic strength, with us are flowing Soma-drops. Next: HYMN IV. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As, Śakra, thou with Manu called Vivasvān drankest Soma juice, As, Indra, thou didst love the hymn by Trita's side, so dost thou joy with Āyu now.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As thou with Mātariśvan, Medhya, Prsadhra, hast cheered thee Indra, with pressed juice, Drunk Soma with Rjunas, Syūmaraśmi, by Dasonya's Dasasipra's side.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ’Tis he who made the lauds his own and boldly drank the Soma juice, He to whom Viṣṇu came striding his three wide steps, as Mitra's statutes ordered it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In whose laud thou didst joy, Indra, at the great deed, O Śatakratu, Mighty One! Seeking renown we call thee as the milkers call the cow who yields abundant milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He is our Sire who gives to us, Great, Mighty, ruling as he wills. Unsought, may he the Strong, Rich, Lord of ample wealth, give us of horses and of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He to whom thou, Good Lord, givest that he may give increases wealth that nourishes. Eager for wealth we call on Indra, Lord of wealth, on Śatakratu with our lauds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Never art thou neglectful: thou guardest both races with thy care. The call on Indra, fourth Āditya! is thine own. Amṛta is stablished in the heavens.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The offercr whom thou, Indra, Lover of the Song, liberal Maghavan, favourest,— As at the call of Kaṇva so, O gracious Lord, hear, thou our songs and eulogy.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sung is the song of ancient time: to Indra have ye said the prayer. They have sung many a Brhati of sacrifice, poured forth the worshipper's many thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra hath tossed together mighty stores of wealth, and both the worlds, yea, and the Sun. Pure, brightly-shining, mingled with the milk, the draughts of Soma have made Indra glad. Next: HYMN V. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As highest of the Maghavans, preeminent among the Bulls, Best breaker-down of forts, kine-winner, Lord of wealth, we seek thee, Indra Maghavan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou who subduedst Āyu, Kutsa, Atithigva, waxing daily in thy might, As such, rousing thy power, we invocate thee now, thee Śatakratu, Lord of Bays.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The pressing-stones shall pour for us the essence of the meath of all, Drops that have been pressed out afar among the folk, and those that have been pressed near us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Repel all enmities and keep thern far away: let all win treasure for their own. Even among Sistas are the stalks that make thee glad, where thou with Soma satest thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come, Indra, very near to us with aids of firmly-based resolve; Come, most auspicious, with thy most auspicious help, good Kinsman, with good kinsmen, come!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bless thou with progeny the chief of men, the lord of heroes, victor in the fray. Aid with thy powers the men who sing thee lauds and keep their spirits ever pure and bright.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May we be such in battle as are surest to obtain thy grace: With holy offerings and invocations of the Gods, we mean, that we may win the spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine, Lord of Bays, am I. Prayer longeth for the spoil. Still with thy help I seek the fight. So, at the raiders' head, I, craving steeds and kine, unite myself with thee alone. Next: HYMN VI. Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: INDRA, the poets with. their hymns extol this hero might of thine: They strengthened, loud in song, thy power that droppeth oil. With hymns the Pauras came to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through piety they came to Indra for his aid, they whose libations give theejoy. As thou with, Krsa and Samvarta hast rejoiced, so, Indra, be thou glad with us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agreeing in your spirit, all ye Deities, come nigh to us. Vasus and Rudras shall come near to give us aid, and Maruts listen to our call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Pūṣan, Viṣṇu, and Sarasvatī befriend, and the Seven Streams, this call of mine: May Waters, Wind, the Mountains, and the Forest-Lord, and Earth give ear unto my cry.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra, with thine own bounteous gift, most liberal of the Mighty Ones, Be our boon benefactor, Vṛtra-slayer, be our feast-companion for our weal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Leader of heroes, Lord of battle, lead thou us to combat, thou Most Sapient One. High fame is theirs who win by invocations, feasts and entertainment of the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Our hopes rest on the Faithful One: in Indra is the people's life. O Maghavan, come nigh that thou mayst give us aid: make plenteous food stream forth for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thee would we worship, Indra, with our songs of praise: O Śatakratu, be thou ours. Pour down upon Praskaṇva bounty vast and firm, exuberant, that shall never fail. Next: HYMN VII. Praskaṇva's Gift.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GREAT, verily, is Indra's might. I have beheld, and hither comes Thy bounty, Dasyave-vrka!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hundred oxen white of hue are shining like the stars in heaven, So tall, they seem to prop the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bamboos a hundred, a hundred dogs, a hundred skins of beasts well-tanned, A hundred tufts of Balbaja, four hundred red-hued mares are mine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Blest by the Gods, Kinvayanas! be ye who spread through life on life: Like horses have ye stridden forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then men extolled the team of seven not yet full-grown, its fame is great. The dark mares rushed along the paths, so that no eye could follow them. Next: HYMN VIII Praskaṇva's Go.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THY bounty, Dasyave-vrka, exhaustless hath displayed itself: Its fulness is as broad as heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ten thousand Dasyave-vrka, the son of Putakrata, hath From his own wealth bestowed on me.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A hundred asses hath he given, a hundred head of fleecy sheep, A hundred slaves, and wreaths besides.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: There also was a mare led forth, picked out for Putakrata's sake, Not of the horses of the herd.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Observant Agni hath appeared, oblation-bearer with his car. Agni with his resplendent flame hath shone on high as shines the Sun, hath shone like Sūrya in theheavens. Next: HYMN IX. Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ENDOWED, O Gods, with your primeval wisdom, come quickly with your chariot, O ye Holy. Come with your mighty powers, O ye Nāsatyas; come hither, drink ye this the third libation.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The truthful Deities, the Three-and-Thirty, saw you approach before the Ever-Truthful. Accepting this our worship and libation, O Aśvins bright with fire, drink ye the Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aśvins, that work of yours deserves our wonder,—the Bull of heaven and earth and air's mid region; Yea, and your thousand promises in battle, -to all of these come near and drink beside us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here is your portion laid for you, ye Holy: come to these songs of ours, O ye Nāsatyas. Drink among us the Soma full of sweetness, and with your powers assist the man who worships. Next: HYMN X. Viśvedevas.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HE whom the priests in sundry ways arranging the sacrifice, of one accord, bring hither, Who was appointed as a learned Brahman, -what is the sacrificer's knowledge of him?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kindled in many a spot, still One is Agni; Silrya is One though high o’er all he shineth. Illumining this All, still One is usas. That which is One hath into All developed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The chariot bright and radiant, treasure-laden, three-wheeled, with easy seat, and lightly rolling, Which She of Wondrous Wealth was born to harness,—this car of yours I call. Drink what remaineth. Next: HYMN XI. Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: IN offerings poured to you, O Indra-Varuṇa, these shares of yours stream forth to glorify your state. Ye haste to the libations at each sacrifice when ye assist the worshipper who sheds the juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The waters and the plants, O Indra-Varuṇa, had efficacious vigour, and attained to might: Ye who have gone beyond the path of middle air,—no godless man is worthy to be called your foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: True is your Krsa's word, Indra and Varuṇa: The seven holy voices pour a wave of meath. For their sake, Lords of splendour! aid the pious man who, unbewildered, keeps you ever in his thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dropping oil, sweet with Soma, pouring forth their stream, are the Seven Sisters in the seat of sacrifice. These, dropping oil, are yours, O Indra-Varuṇa: with these enrich with gifts and help the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To our great happiness have we ascribed to these Two Bright Ones truthfulness, great strength, and majesty. O Lords of splendour, aid us through the Three-times-Seven, as we pour holy oil, O Indra-Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What ye in time of old Indra and Varuṇa, gave Ṛṣis revelation, thought, and power of song, And places which the wise made, weaving sacrifice,—these through my spirit's fervid glow have I beheld.,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra-Varuṇa, grant to the worshippers cheerfulness void of pride, and wealth to nourish them. Next: HYMN I. Soma Pavamana.
